Preoperative Risk Assessment in Older Ad.title: Age, ASA physical status and surgical outcomes: insights from a nationwide cohort study.
Preoperative Risk Assessment in Older Ad.author: Kilhamn N, Eriksson J, von Oelreich E, Jonsson Fagerlund M, Oldner A, Larsson E
Preoperative Risk Assessment in Older Ad.abstract_summary: This nationwide cohort study analyzed over 460,000 surgical procedures in Sweden to examine the relationship between ASA physical status, age, and postoperative mortality. The results show a strong, graded association between higher ASA physical status and increased 30-day and 365-day mortality across all age groups. This association was particularly pronounced in patients with ASA status ≥3, highlighting the tool's continued relevance for risk stratification in an aging surgical population.

Preoperative Risk Assessment in Older Ad.title: Outcomes in patients with chronic heart failure undergoing non-cardiac surgery: a secondary analysis of the METREPAIR international cohort study.
Preoperative Risk Assessment in Older Ad.author: Kirkopoulos A, M'Pembele R, Roth S, Stroda A, Larmann J, Gillmann HJ, Kotfis K, Ganter MT, Bolliger D, Filipovic M, Guzzetti L, Mauermann E, Ionescu D, Spadaro S, Szczeklik W, De Hert S, Beck-Schimmer B, Howell SJ, Lurati Buse GA
Preoperative Risk Assessment in Older Ad.abstract_summary: This secondary analysis of the MET-REPAIR cohort study investigated outcomes for patients with stable chronic heart failure undergoing major non-cardiac surgery. The study found that chronic heart failure was independently associated with a significantly increased risk of 30-day major adverse cardiovascular events, mortality, and severe in-hospital complications. A reduced ejection fraction (<40%) was specifically associated with a higher risk of major adverse cardiovascular events.

Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.title: Adherence to prehabilitation in adult surgical patients: a systematic review, meta-analysis, meta-regression, and qualitative synthesis.
Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.author: Berrio-Valencia MI, Al-Bayati M, Baxi A, Branje K, Chitiva-Martinez I, Hladkowicz E, Kidd G, Hutton B, Wolfe DM, Lalu M, Boet S, Gillis C, McIsaac DI
Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 105 trials found that the average adherence to prehabilitation programs was 79%, but metrics for defining adherence were highly variable. Only older patient age was associated with lower adherence, while qualitative analysis identified logistical issues and health conditions as common barriers. The study calls for standardized adherence metrics and highlights the importance of specialist supervision and program personalization to improve patient engagement.

Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.title: Multimodal prehabilitation as a strategy to reduce postoperative complications in cardiac surgery: A randomised controlled trial.
Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.author: Lopez-Hernandez A, Gimeno-Santos E; Navarro-Ripoll R; Arguis MJ; Lopez-Baamonde M; Sanz-de la Garza M; Sandoval E; Castella M; Martinez-Palli G
Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial evaluated whether a 4-6 week multimodal prehabilitation program could reduce postoperative complications in 151 patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery. The study found no overall difference in the rate of complications between the prehabilitation and control groups. However, a sub-analysis revealed that patients who showed a meaningful response to the exercise component of prehabilitation had significantly fewer and less severe complications.

Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.title: Enhancing Anesthetic Preoptimization: Promising Opportunities for Innovation in Economically Diverse Regions.
Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.author: Bernstein WK, Pearl RG, Huang J, Mayrsohn BG, Mery MW, Banoub M, Pease S, Ayad S, Saffary R, Olszewski RF Jr, Aronson S, Vetter TR
Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.abstract_summary: This review argues for the critical role of anesthesiologists in preoperative patient optimization to improve quality and cost-effectiveness, especially in regions with limited healthcare resources. The paper discusses key medical conditions (e.g., sleep apnea, hypertension, anemia, diabetes) that can be managed preoperatively. It highlights innovations in preoperative care that can reduce morbidity and mortality, emphasizing the anesthesiologist's pivotal position in value-based perioperative management.

Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.title: Understanding preoperative concerns and attitudes towards prehabilitation in older surgical populations: A survey study.
Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.author: Li M, Yan E, Saripella A, Alhamdah Y, Nabipoor M, Alibhai SMH, Wong J, Chung F
Preoperative Optimization and Prehabilit.abstract_summary: This cross-sectional study surveyed 236 older surgical patients to identify their preoperative concerns and attitudes toward prehabilitation. Patients were most concerned about postoperative pain, surgical failure, and complications, with less concern for cognitive or financial issues. While attitudes towards prehabilitation and functional assessments were positive, willingness to undergo preoperative memory testing was low, highlighting an area for improved patient education and engagement.

Surgical Timing and Outcomes.title: Impact of daily, weekly, and seasonal surgical timing on postoperative outcomes in high-risk patients undergoing elective non-cardiac surgery: A retrospective, single-center study.
Surgical Timing and Outcomes.author: Sim JH, Park YS, Park B, Choi Y, Lim JS, Ha S, Kim JU
Surgical Timing and Outcomes.abstract_summary: This retrospective study analyzed 14,394 high-risk patients to assess how surgical timing affects postoperative outcomes. Afternoon surgeries, particularly those between 3:00-6:00 p.m., were associated with higher long-term mortality, more complications, and greater healthcare resource utilization compared to morning surgeries. Seasonal variations were also noted, with summer and winter surgeries linked to higher mortality, suggesting that strategic scheduling could improve outcomes for high-risk patients.

Preoperative Anemia and Iron Deficiency.title: Non-anaemic iron deficiency in surgical patients: more than just a laboratory finding?
Preoperative Anemia and Iron Deficiency.author: Munoz M, Shander A
Preoperative Anemia and Iron Deficiency.abstract_summary: This article discusses the high prevalence of non-anaemic iron deficiency among surgical patients. The authors highlight that the evidence regarding its impact on surgical outcomes is limited and often contradictory. They call for more rigorous investigations with clear definitions to determine whether non-anaemic iron deficiency is a clinically significant condition that warrants preoperative intervention.

Preoperative Anemia and Iron Deficiency.title: Association of non-anaemic iron deficiency with postoperative outcomes after fast-track hip and knee arthroplasty: a prospective cohort study.
Preoperative Anemia and Iron Deficiency.author: Jorgensen CC, Lindberg-Larsen M, Gromov K, Varnum C, Bider MJ, Overgaard S, Andersen MR, Hansen TB, Kehlet H
Preoperative Anemia and Iron Deficiency.abstract_summary: This prospective cohort study involving patients undergoing fast-track hip or knee arthroplasty examined the impact of non-anemic iron deficiency on postoperative outcomes. Although a statistically significant association with days alive and at home was found, the effect was of minimal clinical importance. The study concludes that correcting preoperative iron deficiency without anemia is unlikely to improve common postoperative outcomes in this patient group.

Preoperative Cognitive Screening.title: The utility of the Ascertain Dementia Eight-item Questionnaire (AD8) and Mini-Cog in detecting cognitive impairment in older surgical patients - The Detect CI study.
Preoperative Cognitive Screening.author: Yan E, Alhamdah Y, Campbell S, He D, Lovblom LE, Tang-Wai DF, Saripella A, Wong J, Chung F
Preoperative Cognitive Screening.abstract_summary: This study evaluated two rapid cognitive screening tools, the AD8 and Mini-Cog, against the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) in 394 older surgical patients. Both tools showed moderate accuracy in detecting cognitive impairment (CI), but the AD8 was better associated with poorer preoperative patient-centered assessments and a higher rate of 90-day adverse outcomes. The findings highlight the AD8 as a valuable tool for preoperative screening to identify at-risk older patients.

Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) Discussions.title: Characteristics and outcome of preoperative multidisciplinary team discussions for high-risk noncardiac surgical patients in the Netherlands: a multicentre prospective observational study.
Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) Discussions.author: Vernooij JEM, Hobrink E, Boerlage RM, van Beest P, van de Calseijde S, Holl T, Janssen LMJ, Klinkert L, Marsman M, Nouwen MJ, Wefers Bettink MA, Preckel B, Kalkman CJ, van Leeuwen B, Festen S, Koning NJ
Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) Discussions.abstract_summary: This prospective study observed preoperative multidisciplinary team (MDT) discussions for high-risk noncardiac surgical patients in the Netherlands. The study found that these discussions led to significant changes in clinical management for 81% of patients, with nearly one-third avoiding surgery altogether. Despite this, the rate of postoperative adverse events remained high in the selected surgical population.

Pharmacology of Ketamine.title: Effects of ketamine on postoperative cognition: a scoping review.
Pharmacology of Ketamine.author: Brenna CTA, He XW, Liu D, Kaustov L, Choi S, Orser BA
Pharmacology of Ketamine.abstract_summary: This scoping review summarizes 58 clinical studies on the cognitive effects of ketamine in adult surgical patients. The results are inconsistent, with 60% of studies reporting no cognitive benefit and 40% reporting reduced incidence or duration of perioperative neurocognitive disorders. The authors conclude that due to heterogeneous study designs and underpowered trials, larger, well-designed studies are needed to determine if specific patient subgroups might benefit from ketamine.

Pharmacology of Ketamine.title: Dose-dependent relationship between intra-operative ketamine administration and postoperative delirium: a retrospective cohort study.
Pharmacology of Ketamine.author: Kaiser L, Paschold BS, Wachtendorf LJ, Ahrens E, Tenge T, Redaelli S, Hentges M, Sahli SD, Chen G, Novack V, Eikermann M, Ma H, Schaefer MS
Pharmacology of Ketamine.abstract_summary: This large retrospective cohort study of over 100,000 patients investigated the dose-response relationship between intraoperative ketamine and postoperative delirium. The study found a U-shaped relationship, where low-dose ketamine (≤0.35 mg/kg) was associated with a lower risk of delirium. In contrast, higher doses did not affect delirium risk, suggesting an optimal dose range for its neuroprotective effects.

Intrathecal Opioid Conversion.title: Lost in conversion: navigating the challenges of converting intrathecal opioids to oral equivalents-a case report and literature review.
Intrathecal Opioid Conversion.author: Banik RK, Ko JS, Jiminez F, Horn DB, Sivanesan E, Park M, Cohen SP
Intrathecal Opioid Conversion.abstract_summary: This case report and literature review addresses the challenge of converting chronic intrathecal opioid therapy to systemic opioids, particularly when an intrathecal drug delivery system (IDDS) must be removed. The authors highlight the wide variability in conversion ratios reported in the literature, from 1:300 to as low as 1:2.5 in real-world cases. They advocate for a conservative, patient-specific approach, starting with low conversion ratios and titrating carefully to ensure patient safety.

Novel Anesthetic Agents.title: Comparative Electroencephalographic Profile of a New Anesthetic and Anticonvulsant That Is Selective for the GABA A R Slow Receptor Subtype.
Novel Anesthetic Agents.author: Maciver MB, McCarren HS, Eagleman SL, Davies FM, Jahangir A, Pal D, Mashour GA, Bertaccini EJ
Novel Anesthetic Agents.abstract_summary: This study compared the EEG signature of a novel anesthetic, KSEB 01-S2, which selectively targets the GABA-A-R-slow receptor subtype, with the nonselective agonist propofol in rats. KSEB 01-S2 produced a distinct EEG pattern at loss of consciousness, characterized by an increase in theta power and a decrease in low gamma power, unlike propofol's delta power increase. These findings suggest a mechanistic link between GABA-A receptor subtype specificity and unique EEG frequency signatures during anesthesia.

Novel Anesthetic Agents.title: Effects of the Quinone Analog Ubiquinone-5 on Murine Mitochondria and Hypnosis.
Novel Anesthetic Agents.author: Somnay YR, Wang A, Lim H, Griffiths KK, Zandkarimi F, Chen K, Yang G, Wasilczuk AZ, Kelz MB, Larr D, Yang M, Gil-Iturbe E, Moon A, Quick M, Levy RJ
Novel Anesthetic Agents.abstract_summary: This study investigated the anesthetic properties of ubiquinone-5 (Ub5), a quinone analog, hypothesizing it would act similarly to propofol by disrupting mitochondrial function. In mice, Ub5 induced hypnosis and EEG changes consistent with anesthesia, which was linked to uncompensated mitochondrial proton leak. The research identified the aspartate-glutamate carrier Aralar as a functional target for Ub5, advancing the understanding of how mitochondrial disruption contributes to the anesthetic state.

Perioperative Insulin Pharmacology and M.title: Development of insulin and its pharmacology and perioperative use: a narrative review.
Perioperative Insulin Pharmacology and M.author: Dhatariya K, Levy NA, Stubbs D, Frank C, Tinsley SL, Knaggs RD
Perioperative Insulin Pharmacology and M.abstract_summary: This narrative review covers the evolution of insulin and its perioperative management. It discusses the pharmacology of newer insulin analogues and modern delivery technologies like hybrid closed-loop systems. The authors highlight key considerations for the perioperative team to ensure safe care for patients with diabetes using these advanced treatments.

Perioperative Insulin Pharmacology and M.title: In Vitro Investigation of Insulin Dynamics During 4 Hours of Simulated Cardiopulmonary Bypass.
Perioperative Insulin Pharmacology and M.author: Schweizer T, Nossen CM, Galova B, Schild C, Huber M, Bally L, Vogt A, Siepe M, Nagler M, Fischer K, Guensch DP
Perioperative Insulin Pharmacology and M.abstract_summary: This in vitro study investigated insulin loss during simulated cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) and found a substantial decrease in insulin levels only in circuits containing hemoglobin. The insulin loss was more pronounced in a conventional roller pump circuit compared to a mini-circuit and correlated strongly with the degree of hemolysis. The findings suggest that insulin degradation by hemolysis products is a more significant contributor to insulin loss during CPB than adhesion to circuit surfaces.

Non-Insulin Diabetes Medications in Peri.title: Non-insulin diabetes medicines: a narrative review for anaesthetists and intensivists.
Non-Insulin Diabetes Medications in Peri.author: Tinsley S, Frank C, Stubbs D, Dhatariya K, Knaggs RD, Levy NA
Non-Insulin Diabetes Medications in Peri.abstract_summary: This narrative review provides an overview of non-insulin diabetes medications for anaesthetists and intensivists. It discusses the mechanisms and perioperative considerations for various drug classes, including biguanides, SGLT2 inhibitors, and incretin-based therapies. The article emphasizes safe management strategies to avoid complications when caring for patients on these agents.

Non-Insulin Diabetes Medications in Peri.title: Management of SGLT2i-associated perioperative ketoacidosis (SAPKA) / Euglycemic Diabetic Ketoacidosis (EDKA).
Non-Insulin Diabetes Medications in Peri.author: Wen LY
Non-Insulin Diabetes Medications in Peri.abstract_summary: This infographic provides a concise guide for anesthesia and surgery teams on managing the risk of SGLT2i-associated perioperative ketoacidosis (SAPKA), also known as euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (EDKA). It highlights the incidence of this complication, estimated at 0.17% for non-emergent and 1.1% for emergent procedures. The goal is to improve perioperative management of SGLT2 inhibitors to mitigate this serious risk.

Impact of Legal Decisions on Anesthesia.title: Three Years On: The Impact of the Dobbs Decision on Anesthesia Practice.
Impact of Legal Decisions on Anesthesia.author: Gambling DR, Vogel TM, Markley JC, Traynor AJ, Cohn JH, Morgan CL
Impact of Legal Decisions on Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This article analyzes the effects of the Dobbs decision on anesthesia practice. It highlights that patients seeking abortions now often present at later gestations with more complex medical conditions, posing new challenges for anesthesia providers and necessitating strategies to improve health outcomes.

Occupational Hazards and Workplace Safet.title: Head Strikes Among Perioperative Personnel in the United States: A Mixed Methods Study.
Occupational Hazards and Workplace Safet.author: Piersa AP, Chan KM, Doney A, Copenhaver MS, Gartland RM, Levine WC, Collier LG, Pian-Smith MCM, Tron LE
Occupational Hazards and Workplace Safet.abstract_summary: This national study surveyed anesthesiologists and perioperative nurses about head strikes in the operating room, revealing it as a common yet underreported hazard. Over 78% of respondents reported at least one head strike in the past year, most commonly from monitors and equipment, but only 4.8% filed a safety report. The study calls for multifaceted interventions addressing equipment design, workspace organization, and reporting culture to improve safety.

Emotional Distress and Clinician Well-be.title: "The pain and suffering are just too great for me to manage": A qualitative study of emotional distress among anesthesiologists after challenging clinical events.
Emotional Distress and Clinician Well-be.author: Burns CJ, Marzoughi M, Sinko L, Saddawi-Konefka D, Stratton K, Sigakis M, Wixson M, Simmons S, Ramirez M, Kheterpal S, Was A
Emotional Distress and Clinician Well-be.abstract_summary: This qualitative study interviewed 20 anesthesiology faculty members to explore the sources of lasting emotional distress following challenging clinical events. Key risk factors included clinical errors, unexpected outcomes, lack of support, and patient-related factors like young age. The study highlights the profound and lasting emotional impact on clinicians, including sadness, guilt, and flashbacks, underscoring the need for interventions to protect anesthesiologist mental health.

Gender Equity in Global Anesthesiology.title: The Glass Ceiling in Global Health: Perspectives of Female and Male Anesthesiologists.
Gender Equity in Global Anesthesiology.author: Matejic B, Nelson BD, Collins L, Milenovic MS
Gender Equity in Global Anesthesiology.abstract_summary: This cross-sectional survey of World Federation of Societies of Anaesthesiologists members explored gender differences in perceived barriers to global health careers. The study found that more women than men perceive unique barriers to leadership, with female gender being strongly associated with the perception of bias. Key challenges identified include work-family balance, lack of female mentors, and discrimination, highlighting the need for policies promoting gender equity.

Racial Disparities in Perioperative Care.title: Racial and Ethnic Differences in Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting Care.
Racial Disparities in Perioperative Care.author: Owusu-Agyemang P, Idowu O, Muthukumar A, Guerra-Londono JJ, Idowu T, Diaz NN, Feng L, Miller M, Gundre S, Wright C, Cata JP
Racial Disparities in Perioperative Care.abstract_summary: This retrospective study of over 60,000 cancer surgery patients investigated racial and ethnic differences in the administration of antiemetics. The analysis revealed that Black patients were significantly less likely to receive antiemetics in the preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative settings compared to patients of other races and ethnicities. These findings suggest significant disparities in care for postoperative nausea and vomiting that need to be addressed.

Racial Disparities in Perioperative Care.title: Association between race, ethnicity, and surgical case cancellations: A retrospective study in a cohort of patients undergoing oncological surgeries.
Racial Disparities in Perioperative Care.author: Cata JP, Owusu-Agyemang P, Adesoye T, Feng L
Racial Disparities in Perioperative Care.abstract_summary: This large retrospective study investigated the association between patient race/ethnicity and surgical case cancellations at a major cancer center. The results showed that Black patients had a significantly higher rate of surgical cancellations compared to White and Asian patients, even after adjusting for confounding factors. The study highlights systemic disparities and suggests that in the context of cancer care, Black patients face an increased risk of treatment delays.

Reporting Quality of Clinical Practice G.title: Guidelines on neurostimulation for chronic pain: a compliance appraisal of reporting standards.
Reporting Quality of Clinical Practice G.author: D'Souza RS, Ege E, McMullin P, Hussain N
Reporting Quality of Clinical Practice G.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the reporting quality of 24 clinical practice guidelines on neurostimulation for chronic pain using the RIGHT and AGREE checklists. The findings revealed that current guidelines have significant reporting variability, with an average compliance of only around 55% for both checklists. Key under-reported areas included cost implications, guideline limitations, and management of competing interests, highlighting a need for improved transparency and methodological rigor.

Anesthesiology Residency Program Assessm.title: How Well Do Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education Milestones Track Readiness for Anesthesiology Certifying Examinations in a National Resident Cohort?
Anesthesiology Residency Program Assessm.author: Sun H, Mitchell JD, Deiner SG, Andreae MH, Banerjee A, Ye T, Edgar L, Levine AI, Harman AE, Weinger MB
Anesthesiology Residency Program Assessm.abstract_summary: This study examined the correlation between ACGME Milestones ratings and American Board of Anesthesiology (ABA) examination performance for a national cohort of anesthesiology residents. While a modest correlation was found between the Medical Knowledge Milestone and the written ADVANCED Examination, there were only weak or no significant correlations with the Standardized Oral Examination (SOE) or OSCE. The results suggest that the Milestones system, as currently implemented, does not effectively predict performance on the certifying examinations.

Anesthesiology Residency Program Assessm.title: Reliability and utility of anesthesiology entrustable professional activities assessed with a mobile web application.
Anesthesiology Residency Program Assessm.author: Tanaka P, Park YS, Chen J, Macario A
Anesthesiology Residency Program Assessm.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the use of a mobile web application for assessing 14 Entrustable Professional Activities (EPAs) among 31 anesthesiology residents. The results indicated that only two EPAs were effective in discriminating resident performance, and most EPAs did not reach a level of reliability suitable for formative feedback, even with numerous observations. Despite these limitations, the study concludes that EPA assessments via the app can still be a useful component of competency-based medical education for low-stakes, formative feedback.

EEG-Based Anesthesia Depth Monitoring.title: Response of the Conox quantitative electroencephalographic monitor to neuromuscular block in awake volunteers.
EEG-Based Anesthesia Depth Monitoring.author: Schuller PJ, Pretorius JPG, Newbery KB
EEG-Based Anesthesia Depth Monitoring.abstract_summary: This study investigated whether the Conox EEG monitor, like similar devices, relies on muscle activity (EMG) to generate accurate consciousness indices in awake individuals. By replaying EEG recordings from awake, paralyzed volunteers, the researchers found that both the qCON and qNOX indices decreased to levels indicating sedation or anesthesia, despite the subjects being fully awake. The findings suggest Conox requires EMG for accurate readings and may be an unreliable indicator of awareness in paralyzed patients.

EEG-Based Anesthesia Depth Monitoring.title: Electroencephalographic changes related to cortico-subcortical decoupling during propofol-induced loss of consciousness: A secondary analysis of a prospective observational study.
EEG-Based Anesthesia Depth Monitoring.author: Fernandez-Candil JL, Nuttall R, Gallart L, Schneider G, Blanco-Hinojo L, Martinez-Vilavella G, Pujol J, Adalid I, Berger S, Bujosa D, Deus J, Gambus PL, Jaramillo S, Molto L, Ortega JF, Pacreu S, Perez-Sola V, Vila E
EEG-Based Anesthesia Depth Monitoring.abstract_summary: This secondary analysis aimed to describe artifact-corrected EEG changes that correspond with cortico-subcortical decoupling observed in fMRI during propofol-induced loss of consciousness (LOC). In 16 healthy volunteers, the study found that this decoupling event coincided with a gradual decrease in the qCON index to below 60 and a significant increase in frontal alpha band power. These findings help bridge the gap between fMRI research and clinical EEG monitoring at the bedside.

EEG-Based Anesthesia Depth Monitoring.title: Age-Dependent Entropic Features During Propofol Anesthesia in Developing Brain.
EEG-Based Anesthesia Depth Monitoring.author: Zhang Y, Liang ZH, Wang X, Zhang N, Zhu HT, Wang DX, Guo XY, Li XL, Song LL
EEG-Based Anesthesia Depth Monitoring.abstract_summary: This study investigated the use of entropy-based EEG measures (PeEn and SampEn) for monitoring anesthesia depth in 77 children aged 1-18 receiving propofol. Frontal Permutation Entropy (PeEn) showed excellent accuracy in distinguishing unresponsiveness from recovery, outperforming BIS in toddlers. The study also found that frontal complexity, indicated by these entropic measures, decreased with age during propofol maintenance, reflecting developmental changes in the frontal cortex.

Non-invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring.title: Predicting arterial pressure without prejudice: towards effective hypotension prediction models.
Non-invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring.author: Vistisen ST, Elbers P
Non-invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent study by Yang and colleagues on deep learning models for predicting hypotension. It highlights how training a model with unbiased data selection allows the algorithm to learn more than just the current blood pressure, whereas biased data distorts and inflates the positive predictive value. The authors emphasize the importance of using unbiased data to develop truly effective hypotension prediction algorithms.

Non-invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring.title: A prospective, observational study of non-invasive venous waveform analysis (NIVA) for the detection of acute low volume blood loss in humans.
Non-invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring.author: Alvis BD, Wervey D, Pein R, Wise E, Sobey J, Mede A, Vaughn L, Case M, Breed M, Priyanka J, Leisy P, Brophy C, Hocking K
Non-invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring.abstract_summary: This study evaluated a novel technology, Non-Invasive Venous waveform Analysis (NIVA), for its ability to detect low-volume acute blood loss. In 33 healthy blood donors, the NIVA-derived IntraVAscular Number (IVAN) showed a significant decrease after just 200 mL of blood loss. The technology demonstrated high accuracy (AUC of 0.91) for detecting a 500 mL loss, suggesting its potential as an early, non-invasive monitor for hemorrhage.

Non-invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring.title: Continuous and Noninvasive Total Blood Hemoglobin Measurement Using Near-Infrared Reflectance Spectrometry.
Non-invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring.author: van Wonderen SF, Aguirre A, Benni P, van den Dool REC, Macias Pingarron JP, Solares GJ, Hatib F, Veelo DP, Vlaar APJ, Jian Z
Non-invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring.abstract_summary: This study evaluated a novel algorithm using near-infrared reflectance spectroscopy (NIRS) for continuous, noninvasive measurement of total hemoglobin (tHb) in 189 cardiac surgery patients. The NIRS-based tHb measurements showed good agreement with blood gas analyzer values, with a bias of 0.08 g/dL and precision of 1.01 g/dL. The results suggest this technology provides an accurate measurement of tHb, which could help guide transfusion practices during surgery.

Continuous Glucose Monitoring.title: Accuracy of continuous glucose monitoring during noncardiac surgery: a prospective, blinded observational multicentre cohort study.
Continuous Glucose Monitoring.author: Janssen H, Dias P, Ahuja S, Alharbi S, Hiller L, Khan K, Iyer K, Sundar A, Abousharkh I, Thomas C, Jhanji S, Oliver NS, AcklandGL
Continuous Glucose Monitoring.abstract_summary: This prospective study evaluated the accuracy of a continuous glucose monitor (Dexcom G7) during the perioperative period in 118 noncardiac surgery patients. Compared to arterial blood glucose measurements, the monitor showed an overall bias of 0.38 mM, which decreased by the end of surgery. With over 98% of values falling within acceptable risk ranges, the study concludes that the accuracy of modern continuous glucose monitoring is sufficient for perioperative use to enhance surveillance of dysglycemia.

Sustainability and Environmental Impact.title: Impact of desflurane removal from the operating room on carbon dioxide emissions at a tertiary academic medical centre: a retrospective analysis.
Sustainability and Environmental Impact.author: Seibold EL, Wachtendorf LJ, Needham MJ, Munoz-Acuna R, Redaelli S, Suleiman A, von Wedel D, Ratajczak N, Remotti EJ, Paschold BS, Chen G, Palardy A, Pierce T, Kienbaum P, Ramachandran SK, Schaefer MS
Sustainability and Environmental Impact.abstract_summary: This retrospective study analyzed the impact of removing desflurane on anesthesia-related carbon emissions at a U.S. academic medical center. The gradual removal and ultimate elimination of desflurane led to an 82.8% reduction in CO2e-emissions per patient. The study highlights that after eliminating desflurane, the use of nitrous oxide and high fresh gas flows became the dominant contributors to the remaining carbon footprint.

Sustainability and Environmental Impact.title: Sustainability assessment of perioperative patient warming devices: a comparative life cycle assessment and costing.
Sustainability and Environmental Impact.author: Rebello TA, Spoyalo K, Chhipi-Shrestha G, Hewage K, Sadiq R, MacNeill AJ
Sustainability and Environmental Impact.abstract_summary: This study conducted a life cycle assessment and costing analysis of various perioperative patient warming devices. The resistive blanket was found to be the most environmentally and economically sustainable option. The authors recommend minimizing the use of flannel blankets and disposable consumables to optimize sustainability.

Artificial Intelligence in Anesthesia.title: Mean arterial pressure is all you need in a machine learning model for mean arterial pressure prediction.
Artificial Intelligence in Anesthesia.author: Tschoellitsch T, Kaltenleithner S, Maletzky A, Moser P, Seidl P, Bock C, Thumfart S, Giretzlehner M, Hochreiter S, Meier J
Artificial Intelligence in Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This retrospective study evaluated whether machine learning models could predict mean arterial pressure (MAP) using only previous MAP values as input. Using three large patient datasets, the models achieved high predictive accuracy (ROC AUCs >0.92 for a 5-minute horizon) for MAP falling below 65 mmHg. The study concludes that complex inputs are not necessary, as a model trained solely on past MAP data can effectively predict future hypotension.

Artificial Intelligence in Anesthesia.title: Artificial intelligence for electrocardiographic diagnosis of perioperative myocardial ischaemia: a scoping review.
Artificial Intelligence in Anesthesia.author: Kim A, Chatterjee M, Iansavitchene A, Komeili M, Chan ADC, Yang H, Chui J
Artificial Intelligence in Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This scoping review assessed the current state of artificial intelligence (AI) for diagnosing perioperative myocardial ischemia from ECGs. The review of 182 articles found that while AI algorithms can achieve high diagnostic accuracy on clean, intermittent ECGs from existing databases, they have not been validated on 'noisy' continuous data typical of the perioperative setting. The authors call for future research to develop and test AI algorithms on real-world perioperative ECG data.

Artificial Intelligence in Anesthesia.title: Generative AI models: the next anaesthetic agent?
Artificial Intelligence in Anesthesia.author: Julius A, Bowness JS
Artificial Intelligence in Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent study that used an ensemble of large language models (LLMs) to accurately extract structured data from free-text intraoperative transesophageal echocardiography reports. The authors highlight the potential of this AI-driven approach to overcome the challenges of manual data extraction, which is often labor-intensive and error-prone. This technology points towards broader applications of AI in streamlining data management and improving efficiency in perioperative care.

Remote Continuous Monitoring.title: Remote Continuous Vital Sign Monitoring of Scoliosis Surgery Patients on General Wards: A Cost-Effectiveness Analysis.
Remote Continuous Monitoring.author: Trentino KM, Hoque ME, Lloyd A, Trentino L, Ienco R, Murray K, Bowles T, Wulff S, Burcham J, Thompson A, Waterer G
Remote Continuous Monitoring.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the cost-effectiveness of a remote continuous monitoring service (HIVE) for postoperative scoliosis surgery patients on general wards. Comparing patients before and after HIVE implementation, the service was associated with a reduction of 27.1 hours in ICU and a cost saving of AU$2682 per patient. The findings provide economic evidence supporting the use of remote monitoring to reduce ICU utilization and healthcare costs without compromising patient safety.

Operational Response to Electronic Healt.title: Continuing Anesthesia Services in the Face of a Prolonged Digital Health System Outage.
Operational Response to Electronic Healt.author: Cheon EC, Shaffer S, McCarthy K, Leavitt O, Mukerji S, Hardy C
Operational Response to Electronic Healt.abstract_summary: This narrative review details a pediatric anesthesiology department's experience during a prolonged electronic health record (EHR) system outage. The authors describe the operational challenges and responses needed to maintain safe patient care and financial stability. They provide recommendations for other hospitals on managing such disruptions, which affect all aspects of care from patient identification to communication.

Perioperative Education and Technology.title: Technology, evidence, and continuing clinical education: a role for self-directed learning?
Perioperative Education and Technology.author: Webster CS, Weller JM
Perioperative Education and Technology.abstract_summary: This article discusses the challenge for clinicians to stay updated with rapidly advancing clinical technology in anesthesia. It highlights self-directed learning, particularly through video, as an effective and flexible method to meet this training need. However, the authors suggest that this approach is unlikely to completely replace traditional instructor-led learning.

Videolaryngoscopy Techniques and Trainin.title: Incidence of transient sinus pause in cardiac rhythm increases with the use of hyperangulated videolaryngoscope blade compared to standard angle blade during tracheal intubation: A prospective randomised controlled trial.
Videolaryngoscopy Techniques and Trainin.author: Lee YJ, Lee S, Kim JW, Oh CS, Kim TY
Videolaryngoscopy Techniques and Trainin.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial compared the hemodynamic effects of hyperangulated versus standard-angle videolaryngoscope blades during intubation. The study found a significantly higher incidence of transient sinus pause (19% vs. 4%) in the group using the hyperangulated blade. Use of the hyperangulated blade was identified as an independent predictor for this adverse cardiac rhythm event.

Videolaryngoscopy Techniques and Trainin.title: Videolaryngoscopy versus direct laryngoscopy for teaching direct laryngoscopy skills: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Videolaryngoscopy Techniques and Trainin.author: Gunning SGS, Urwin D, Cook TM, Hansel J
Videolaryngoscopy Techniques and Trainin.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis assessed the utility of Macintosh videolaryngoscopy for teaching direct laryngoscopy. Analysis of 10 relevant studies showed that training with videolaryngoscopy led to higher first-attempt success rates compared to direct laryngoscopy training. The review concludes that videolaryngoscopy is an effective tool for teaching direct laryngoscopy skills and its role as a preferred teaching method should be considered.

Tracheal Extubation Location and Postope.title: Impact of tracheal extubation location after surgical procedures on peri-operative times: a prospective dual-centre observational study.
Tracheal Extubation Location and Postope.author: Godet T, Wajew C, Fabrizi M, Monet C, Pouzeratte Y, Lapeyre M, Adelou S, Pereira B, Garnier M, Chanques G, Jabaudon M, Futier E, Jaber S, De Jong A
Tracheal Extubation Location and Postope.abstract_summary: This prospective study compared outcomes based on the location of tracheal extubation—either in the operating theatre (OT) or the post-anaesthesia care unit (PACU). The results showed that extubating in the OT added approximately 8 minutes to theatre occupancy time. However, it was associated with a lower incidence of postoperative respiratory and cardiovascular complications like desaturation and hypotension.

Pediatric Airway Management and Complica.title: Consensus recommendations for paediatric airway topicalisation using lidocaine.
Pediatric Airway Management and Complica.author: Iliff HA, Parnell J, Baker PA, Baxter A, Chapman R, Coulson J, Dotherty C, Endlich Y, Frykholm P, Harkin J, Jagannathan N, Kubba H, Kwizera Ndekezi J, McGuire B, Mesbah A, Mehanna R, Miskovic A, Newton R, Orban N, Perry S, Peyton J, Rivett K, Roberts M, Temo K
Pediatric Airway Management and Complica.abstract_summary: This paper presents consensus recommendations developed by an international expert group on the use of lidocaine for airway topicalization in children. Following a systematic review and a Delphi process, 21 recommendations were agreed upon, covering dosing, recovery, adverse reactions, and institutional responsibilities. These guidelines aim to promote safer clinical practice, addressing a gap in current evidence-based guidance.

Pediatric Airway Management and Complica.title: Adverse events associated with airway management in pediatric anesthesia: A prospective, multicenter, observational Japan Pediatric Difficult Airway in Anesthesia (J-PEDIA) study.
Pediatric Airway Management and Complica.author: Kojima T, Yamauchi Y, Watanabe F, Ichiyanagi S, Kobayashi Y, Kaiho Y, Toyama H, Kasuya S, Kuratani N, Suzuki Y
Pediatric Airway Management and Complica.abstract_summary: The J-PEDIA study prospectively observed over 17,000 airway management procedures in children across 10 Japanese hospitals to determine the incidence of adverse events. Any adverse event occurred in 2.0% of cases, with desaturation occurring in 2.3%, most frequently in neonates and infants. Risk factors included younger age, certain surgical types, and anatomical difficult airway features, highlighting areas for targeted safety strategies.

High-Flow Nasal Oxygen vs. Laryngeal Mas.title: High-Flow Nasal Oxygen versus Mechanical Ventilation Through a Laryngeal Mask During General Anesthesia Without Muscle Paralysis: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
High-Flow Nasal Oxygen vs. Laryngeal Mas.author: Frassanito L, Grieco DL, Vassalli F, Piersanti A, Scorzoni M, Ciano F, Zanfini BA, Catarci S, Catena U, Scambia G, Antonelli M, Draisci G
High-Flow Nasal Oxygen vs. Laryngeal Mas.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared high-flow nasal oxygen with laryngeal mask ventilation for respiratory support during 30-minute general anesthesia sessions without muscle paralysis. The study found high-flow oxygen to be non-inferior, with a 99% success rate in both groups. While high-flow oxygen was associated with fewer postoperative respiratory symptoms, it also led to a higher incidence of hypercarbia, warranting careful patient selection and monitoring.

Emergency Front-of-Neck Access in Pediat.title: 'The trachea heals but the hypoxia does not' an emergency front-of-neck access in a 4-year-old with foreign body airway obstruction.
Emergency Front-of-Neck Access in Pediat.author: Asgeirsdottir S, Karlsson EK, Sigurdsson T
Emergency Front-of-Neck Access in Pediat.abstract_summary: This case report details a life-threatening 'Can't Intubate Can't Oxygenate' (CICO) emergency in a 4-year-old child with a foreign body airway obstruction. The report describes the successful use of an emergency front-of-neck surgical airway (eFONA) via a scalpel-bougie-tube method during cardiopulmonary resuscitation. This case highlights a critical intervention for a rare but devastating event in the pediatric population.

Perioperative Fasting Guidelines for Chi.title: Impact of liberal preoperative clear fluid fasting regimens on the risk of pulmonary aspiration in children (EUROFAST): an international prospective cohort study.
Perioperative Fasting Guidelines for Chi.author: Frykholm P, Modiri AR, Klaucane A, Beck CE, Bouvet L, Isserman RS, Oshan V, Stricker PA, Quintao VC, Frithiof R
Perioperative Fasting Guidelines for Chi.abstract_summary: This large, international prospective cohort study involving over 300,000 pediatric anesthetic procedures investigated the safety of liberalized clear fluid fasting times. The study found no increase in the incidence of confirmed pulmonary aspiration when fasting times were reduced from ≥2 hours to either ≥1 hour or a 'sip-til-send' policy. The findings provide strong evidence for the safety of reducing preoperative clear fluid fasting times to 1 hour or less in children.

Neurocognitive Effects of Inhaled Anesth.title: Emergence from general anaesthesia: stochastic or deterministic?
Neurocognitive Effects of Inhaled Anesth.author: Lee U
Neurocognitive Effects of Inhaled Anesth.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent study on emergence from anesthesia, which found significant variability in emergence times even in genetically identical mice, suggesting a stochastic rather than deterministic process. The author argues that while this offers a new perspective, the reliance on motor reflexes (like the righting reflex) may not fully capture cognitive recovery. The commentary calls for future research to use more comprehensive, cognition-sensitive markers to better understand the nature of anesthetic emergence.

Neurocognitive Effects of Inhaled Anesth.title: Intergenerational Postoperative Neurocognitive Disorder in a Rat Model: Initiating Mechanisms and Pharmacological Prevention.
Neurocognitive Effects of Inhaled Anesth.author: Ju LS, Khan ZA, Gravenstein N, Seubert CN, Setlow B, Martynyuk AE
Neurocognitive Effects of Inhaled Anesth.abstract_summary: This study in rats explored the mechanisms of sevoflurane-induced perioperative neurocognitive disorder (PND) and its potential intergenerational transmission. Sevoflurane exposure in adult male rats led to sustained hormonal and inflammatory changes and behavioral deficits, which were prevented by an NKCC1 inhibitor or a glucocorticoid receptor inhibitor. Notably, the male offspring of sevoflurane-exposed rats also exhibited similar behavioral abnormalities, suggesting an intergenerational effect of PND that could be pharmacologically prevented.

Neurocognitive Effects of Inhaled Anesth.title: Direct inhibition of cystathionine-beta-synthase by isoflurane contributes to delayed neurocognitive recovery after isoflurane general anaesthesia in mice.
Neurocognitive Effects of Inhaled Anesth.author: Xu F, Zhang P, Liu H, Wang R, Fan Z, Gao Y, Lu Z, Cong P, Chen H, Wang J, Dong H, Xiong L, Zhao G
Neurocognitive Effects of Inhaled Anesth.abstract_summary: This study investigated how isoflurane affects postoperative neurocognitive recovery in mice. Researchers found that isoflurane directly inhibits the enzyme cystathionine-beta-synthase (CBS), leading to an accumulation of homocysteine in the brain and delayed cognitive recovery. Activating CBS or its downstream pathways was shown to alleviate these cognitive deficits, providing a new insight into the mechanisms of perioperative neurocognitive disorders (PND).

Factors Associated with MAC Ratio.title: Clinical and Genetic Factors Associated with Intraoperative Minimum Alveolar Concentration Ratio: A Single-center Retrospective Cohort and Genome-wide Association Study.
Factors Associated with MAC Ratio.author: Douville NJ, Jewell ES, Zhao X, Colquhoun DA, Bertucci-Richter E, Zollner S, Davis RP, Kumar SS, Mashour GA
Factors Associated with MAC Ratio.abstract_summary: This large retrospective study investigated clinical and genetic factors associated with the clinically delivered minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) ratio. The study confirmed that mean arterial pressure was strongly associated with anesthetic delivery and identified numerous other demographic and surgical factors. A genome-wide association study suggested several plausible genes, including DISC1, but no variants reached genome-wide significance.

Postoperative Sleep Quality.title: Propofol versus sevoflurane anesthesia on postoperative sleep quality in older patients after major abdominal surgery: A randomized clinical trial.
Postoperative Sleep Quality.author: Chen NP, Sun P, Li CJ, Xing XX, Li M, Sun ZJ, Li HJ, Mu DL, Wang DX
Postoperative Sleep Quality.abstract_summary: This randomized clinical trial compared the effects of propofol versus sevoflurane anesthesia on postoperative sleep in 144 older patients undergoing major abdominal surgery. The study found that propofol-based anesthesia was associated with a significantly longer total sleep time on the first postoperative night compared to sevoflurane. This difference may be partly explained by lower plasma orexin-A levels in the propofol group.

Environmental Impact of Inhaled Anesthet.title: Views of people who have given birth on the environmental and occupational exposure risks of nitrous oxide for labour analgesia: an interview-based qualitative study.
Environmental Impact of Inhaled Anesthet.author: Elgie L, Salih T, Moonesinghe SR
Environmental Impact of Inhaled Anesthet.abstract_summary: This qualitative study explored the perspectives of 12 individuals who had used nitrous oxide for labor analgesia regarding its environmental and occupational risks. Participants viewed nitrous oxide as a safe, default option and felt that mitigating its harm was the institution's responsibility, not the patient's. While they were interested in its environmental impact, this information would not necessarily change their choice of analgesia, highlighting the need for system-level solutions.

Propofol Pharmacometabolomics.title: Breath Analysis of Propofol and Associated Metabolic Signatures: A Pilot Study Using Secondary Electrospray Ionization-High-resolution Mass Spectrometry.
Propofol Pharmacometabolomics.author: Zeng J, Stankovic N, Singh KD, Steiner R, Frey U, Erb T, Sinues P
Propofol Pharmacometabolomics.abstract_summary: This pilot study explored the use of high-resolution mass spectrometry to analyze the breath of pediatric patients under propofol anesthesia. The results showed a strong correlation between exhaled propofol and its metabolites with serum concentrations. The analysis also detected metabolic changes indicative of oxidative stress, demonstrating the potential of real-time breath analysis for individualized anesthetic monitoring.

Remimazolam for General Anesthesia in Ol.title: Incidence of postoperative delirium and quality of recovery in older patients undergoing gastrectomy under general anaesthesia with remimazolam vs. propofol: a randomised non-inferiority study.
Remimazolam for General Anesthesia in Ol.author: Sim JH, Kim KM, Lee U, Lee EK, Noh GJ, Choi BM
Remimazolam for General Anesthesia in Ol.abstract_summary: This randomized non-inferiority trial compared remimazolam and propofol for maintenance of general anesthesia in 432 older patients undergoing gastrectomy. The study found no difference in the incidence of postoperative delirium (7.9% in both groups) or in the quality of recovery scores at 24 hours. The results suggest that remimazolam is a viable alternative to propofol regarding these key postoperative outcomes.

Neural Mechanisms of Propofol.title: The role of supramammillary nucleus glutamatergic neurons in modulating consciousness transitions during propofol anesthesia in mice.
Neural Mechanisms of Propofol.author: Li JY, Wu YH, Wang YH, Long S, Hu R, Huang WQ, Wang ZX
Neural Mechanisms of Propofol.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of glutamatergic neurons in the supramammillary nucleus (SuM) in propofol-induced anesthesia in mice. The activity of these neurons decreased during induction and increased during recovery. Manipulating these neurons via chemogenetics and optogenetics altered anesthesia induction/recovery times and could induce behavioral arousal, demonstrating their crucial role in modulating consciousness transitions during propofol anesthesia.

Cognitive Effects of Sedatives.title: Effects of Sedative Doses of Propofol, Dexmedetomidine, and Fentanyl on Memory and Pain in Healthy Young Adults: A Randomized, Controlled, Single-blind Crossover Study Using Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging at 7 Tesla.
Cognitive Effects of Sedatives.author: Vogt KM, Simmons MA, Reddy SN, Burlew AC, Kozdron CN, Lavage DR, Wang S, Pryor KO, Shafer SL, Ibrahim T, Aizenstein HJ, Reder LM, Ibinson JW, Fiez JA
Cognitive Effects of Sedatives.abstract_summary: This 7T fMRI study in healthy volunteers compared the effects of low-dose propofol, dexmedetomidine, and fentanyl on memory and pain perception. Propofol significantly impaired memory recollection and reduced pain-related brain activation in key areas like the insula, amygdala, and hippocampus. Dexmedetomidine and fentanyl showed different patterns of brain activation changes, highlighting the distinct neuroanatomic targets and cognitive effects of these common sedative agents.

Novel Reversal Agents.title: Efficacy and safety of adamgammadex for reversing rocuronium-induced deep neuromuscular block: a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, positive-controlled phase III trial.
Novel Reversal Agents.author: Zhao Y, Ren Y, Xie W, Wang Y, Lei Y, Zhu Y, Zhang X, Wu X, Guo X, Jiang Y, Wang S, Lei Q, You J, Yu Y, Zhou Y, Zhou W, Xu G, Li C, Gu Z, Luo F, Wang H, Chen J, Wang R, Qi Y, Jie Q, Su D, Gu X, Yu W
Novel Reversal Agents.abstract_summary: This Phase III randomized trial compared the new reversal agent adamgammadex with sugammadex for reversing deep rocuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade. The study found that adamgammadex (8 mg/kg) was non-inferior to sugammadex (4 mg/kg) in achieving a train-of-four ratio of 0.9 within 10 minutes. The safety profiles of both drugs were comparable.

Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.title: The effect of methylprednisolone on the reversal time of rocuronium by sugammadex in the paediatric patient group: A randomised controlled trial.
Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.author: Buyukcavlak M, Tire Y, Mermer A, Yuce MS, Yildirim SN, Kozanhan B
Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial investigated whether methylprednisolone administration affects sugammadex reversal time in pediatric patients. The study found that patients receiving methylprednisolone had a statistically significant but clinically minor prolongation of reversal time (mean difference of 34.5 seconds) and extubation time. The authors conclude that while an interaction exists, its clinical importance is minimal.

Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Sugammadex versus Neostigmine for Reversal of Rocuronium on Gastric Emptying in Adults Undergoing Elective Colorectal Surgery.
Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.author: Togioka BM, Rakshe SK, Ye S, Tekkali P, Tsikitis VL, Fang SH, Herzig DO, Lu KC, Aziz MF
Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared sugammadex to neostigmine-glycopyrrolate for rocuronium reversal in colorectal surgery, focusing on gastrointestinal function. The study found no significant difference in gastric emptying (primary outcome) between the two groups. However, sugammadex was associated with a faster time to adequate reversal and a clinically significant 16.7-hour shorter time to first bowel movement.

Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.title: The immunomodulatory effect of sugammadex in vitro and after total hip arthroplasty : A randomised controlled pilot and retrospective cohort study.
Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.author: Bijkerk V, Jacobs LMC, Visser J, van Helden EV, Keijzer C, Helder LS, Albers KI, Warle MC
Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.abstract_summary: This study investigated the immunomodulatory effects of sugammadex through in-vitro, pilot, and retrospective cohort analyses. In vitro, sugammadex restored cytokine production suppressed by rocuronium. However, a clinical pilot study in total hip arthroplasty patients and a retrospective cohort study in major abdominal surgery patients found no significant early postoperative immunomodulatory effects or association with infectious complications at clinically used doses.

Neuromuscular Blockade and Postoperative.title: Deep versus Moderate Neuromuscular Blockade During Total Hip Replacement Surgery on Postoperative Recovery and Immune Function: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
Neuromuscular Blockade and Postoperative.author: Bijkerk V, Jacobs LMC, Rijnen WHC, Keijzer C, Warle MC, Visser J
Neuromuscular Blockade and Postoperative.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial compared deep versus moderate neuromuscular blockade (NMB) in 100 patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty. The study found no significant difference between the two groups in the primary outcome of quality of recovery at postoperative day 1. There were also no differences in postoperative inflammation or pain scores, suggesting no clear benefit of deep NMB for this type of surgery.

Neuromuscular Blockade and Postoperative.title: Association Between Neuromuscular Blockade and Its Reversal With Postoperative Delirium in Older Patients: A Hospital Registry Study.
Neuromuscular Blockade and Postoperative.author: Ahrens E, Wachtendorf LJ, Shay D, Tenge T, Paschold BS, Rudolph MI, Redaelli S, Kaiser L, Suleiman A, Ma H, Fassbender PJ, Schaefer MS
Neuromuscular Blockade and Postoperative.abstract_summary: This large hospital registry study of over 53,000 older patients found that the use of nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents (ND-NMBAs) was dose-dependently associated with a higher risk of postoperative delirium. However, this increased risk was mitigated by the administration of a reversal agent (sugammadex or neostigmine). The study concludes that routine reversal of neuromuscular blockade may help reduce the incidence of delirium after surgery.

Recovery from Minimal Neuromuscular Bloc.title: Recovery of the acute hypoxic ventilatory response after reversal of a minimal neuromuscular block. A randomized, controlled trial in healthy, non-obese volunteers.
Recovery from Minimal Neuromuscular Bloc.author: Snoek MAJ, van Lemmen MA, van der Schrier R, van Velzen M, Dahan A, Boon M
Recovery from Minimal Neuromuscular Bloc.abstract_summary: This study in healthy volunteers investigated the recovery of the acute hypoxic ventilatory response (AHVR) after reversal of a minimal neuromuscular block. Results showed that AHVR was depressed during the block and remained depressed at the point of symptomatic recovery. Although sugammadex reversal resulted in fewer patients with residual AHVR depression compared to spontaneous recovery, a considerable proportion of patients in all groups had residual depression 40 minutes after recovery.

Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.title: Comparison of two peripheral regional analgesic techniques for primary elective total hip arthroplasty: a randomised clinical trial.
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.author: Buffoli F, Bonetti C, Pugno C, Minini A, Bettinelli S, Mancini A, Colombi A, Benigni A, Mariano ER, Lorini LF, Bugada D
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared two motor-sparing regional techniques for total hip arthroplasty: a pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block plus lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block versus an erector spinae plane (ESP) block. The study found no statistically or clinically significant difference between the two techniques in terms of 24-hour morphine consumption or other secondary outcomes. The choice of block may therefore be situation-dependent, based on patient and system factors.

Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.title: Pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block compared to intrathecal morphine for analgesic efficacy in total hip arthroplasty: A placebo-controlled randomized double-blind non-inferiority trial.
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.author: Oremus K, Trkulja V, Gasparini G, Sostaric S, Cicak N, Haspl M, Mihaljevic S
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.abstract_summary: This randomized, double-blind non-inferiority trial compared the analgesic efficacy of a pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block to intrathecal (IT) morphine in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty. The study found that the PENG block was non-inferior to IT morphine for pain control at rest and during movement over 48 hours, with similar rescue opioid consumption. Importantly, the PENG block did not cause additional motor function compromise.

Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.title: Regional anaesthesia modalities for primary total hip arthroplasty: a systematic review and component network meta-analysis.
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.author: Lee KH, Wang JC, Chang CY, Teng WN, Wang HY, Lee CC, Tsai SW, Chen CF, Wu PK, Chen WM
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.abstract_summary: This systematic review and network meta-analysis compared various single-shot regional anesthesia techniques for primary total hip arthroplasty. The analysis of 87 trials concluded that combined modalities, particularly pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block plus local infiltrative analgesia (LIA), are favorable. This combination provides lower pain scores and reduced opioid consumption with motor-sparing effects.

Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.title: Postsurgical opioid prescribing among veterans using community care for orthopedic surgery at non-VA hospitals compared to a VA hospital with a transitional pain service: a retrospective cohort study.
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.author: Buys MJ, Anderson Z, Bayless K, Zhang C, Presson AP, Hales J, Brooke BS
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Arthroplasty.abstract_summary: This retrospective cohort study compared postoperative opioid prescribing for veterans undergoing orthopedic joint surgery at non-VA community hospitals versus a VA medical center (VAMC) with a transitional pain service. Veterans treated at non-VHA hospitals were prescribed significantly more opioids at discharge and within the first 90 days post-surgery. They were also more likely to continue filling opioid prescriptions beyond 90 days, suggesting that integrated transitional pain services may reduce high-risk prescribing.

Regional Anesthesia for Hip Fracture.title: Comparing the pericapsular nerve group block and fascia iliaca block for acute pain management in patients with hip fracture: a randomised clinical trial.
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Fracture.author: Di Pietro S, Maffeis R, Jannelli E, Mascia B, Resta F, De Silvestri A, Musella V, Centurioni CE, Regeni E, Grassi FA, Locatelli A, Perlini S
Regional Anesthesia for Hip Fracture.abstract_summary: This randomized clinical trial compared the pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block with the fascia iliaca block (FIB) for acute pain in patients with hip fractures. The study found that the PENG block provided superior analgesia in the first hour post-block, with a significantly greater reduction in pain scores. This suggests the PENG block is a promising modality for acute pain management in this setting.

Regional Anesthesia for Breast Surgery.title: Erector spinae plane block versus paravertebral block for major oncological breast surgery: a multicentre randomised controlled trial.
Regional Anesthesia for Breast Surgery.author: Raft J, Dureau S, Fuzier R, Auge M, Lamotte AS, Lemoine A, Albi-Feldzer A
Regional Anesthesia for Breast Surgery.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared the efficacy of erector spinae plane block (ESPB) and thoracic paravertebral block (PVB) for pain management after major breast cancer surgery. The study found that ESPB did not meet non-inferiority criteria and was less effective for complete analgesia compared to PVB. PVB provided more reliable dermatomal coverage and remains the preferred technique for major breast surgery.

Regional Anesthesia for Breast Surgery.title: Opioid-free anaesthesia protocol based on thoracic paravertebral block enhances postoperative recovery after breast cancer surgery: A two-center, prospective, randomized, controlled trial.
Regional Anesthesia for Breast Surgery.author: Tong P, Guo Y, Wang Y, Feng Y, Song X, Luo G, Qin W, Lu X, Zheng L, Wang H, Lu Y, Lai R
Regional Anesthesia for Breast Surgery.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial evaluated an opioid-free anesthesia (OFA) protocol based on thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) for patients undergoing breast cancer surgery. Compared to standard opioid-based anesthesia, the OFA protocol resulted in significantly higher Quality of Recovery-15 scores at 24 and 48 hours postoperatively. The OFA group also experienced lower pain scores and fewer instances of nausea and retching.

Quadratus Lumborum (QL) Block.title: Unilateral subcostal anterior quadratus lumborum block versus intrathecal morphine for postoperative pain in laparoscopic nephrectomy: a randomized controlled trial.
Quadratus Lumborum (QL) Block.author: Kaya C, Dost B, Turunc E, Ustun YB, Kibar AN, Cebeci H, De Cassai A; Elsharkawy H
Quadratus Lumborum (QL) Block.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared a unilateral anterior subcostal quadratus lumborum (QL) block to intrathecal morphine (ITM) for pain after laparoscopic nephrectomy. The QL block did not meet the non-inferiority margin for 24-hour opioid consumption, with ITM providing lower pain scores and greater patient satisfaction. The study suggests QL block may be less effective due to inconsistent cranial spread and limited visceral analgesia.

Quadratus Lumborum (QL) Block.title: No quadriceps muscle weakness following anterior quadratus lumborum block compared with placebo: a randomized, non-inferiority, blinded, volunteer trial.
Quadratus Lumborum (QL) Block.author: Tanggaard K, Nielsen MV, Holm UHU, Hoffmann BM, Bernhoff C, Andersen CH, Thomassen SS, Hansen C, Dam M, Poulsen TD, Holm PM, Borglum J
Quadratus Lumborum (QL) Block.abstract_summary: This randomized, non-inferiority trial in 20 healthy volunteers investigated whether a unilateral anterior quadratus lumborum (QL) block causes quadriceps muscle weakness. The study found no statistically or clinically significant difference in quadriceps strength between the active block and placebo. This suggests the block can be safely used for procedures where early mobilization is crucial, without compromising motor function.

Parasternal Intercostal Plane (PIP) Bloc.title: Impact of superficial and deep parasternal blocks on recovery after cardiac surgery with sternotomy: a randomised controlled trial.
Parasternal Intercostal Plane (PIP) Bloc.author: Demarquette A, Jeanneteau A, Blanchard-Daguet A, Fouquet O, Parot-Schinkel E, Lasocki S, Rineau E, Leger M
Parasternal Intercostal Plane (PIP) Bloc.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial assessed whether superficial or deep parasternal intercostal plane blocks improve quality of recovery after cardiac surgery with sternotomy compared to standard care. The study found no significant improvement in Quality of Recovery-15 scores at 24 hours for either block group. Postoperative pain and analgesic consumption were also similar across all three groups, suggesting limited benefit of these blocks for this procedure.

Parasternal Intercostal Plane (PIP) Bloc.title: Maximum extension and regression rate of cutaneous sensory block: superficial vs. deep parasternal intercostal plane blocks in patients undergoing open cardiac surgery.
Parasternal Intercostal Plane (PIP) Bloc.author: Dost B, Turunc E, Kaya C, Sahin CA, Genc C, Yucel SM, Demirag MK; Karakaya D
Parasternal Intercostal Plane (PIP) Bloc.abstract_summary: This prospective study compared the sensory block characteristics of superficial (S-PIP) and deep (D-PIP) parasternal intercostal plane blocks after open cardiac surgery. Both techniques provided comparable and extensive sensory coverage of the anterior thorax, primarily from T2-T6, with no significant differences in postoperative pain or opioid consumption. The sensory block persisted at 12 hours and partially regressed by 24 hours.

Pharmacokinetics of Local Anesthetics in.title: Pharmacokinetic modelling and simulation for prolonged infusion of levobupivacaine with or without epinephrine in transversus abdominis plane and erector spinae plane blocks: a randomised controlled trial and analysis of pooled data.
Pharmacokinetics of Local Anesthetics in.author: Araneda A, De la Cuadra JC, Corvetto M, Balde D, Fuente R, Ibacache M, Contreras V, Solari S, Cortinez I
Pharmacokinetics of Local Anesthetics in.abstract_summary: This study analyzed the pharmacokinetics of levobupivacaine in erector spinae plane (ESP) and transversus abdominis plane (TAP) blocks. The addition of epinephrine significantly reduced the systemic absorption of levobupivacaine by lowering its bioavailability and prolonging its absorption half-life. Simulations suggested that extended dosing regimens of 300 mg per 24 hours for 48 hours are likely to remain below toxic thresholds.

General vs. Regional Anesthesia for Arth.title: Regional versus general anesthesia for total hip and knee arthroplasty: a nationwide retrospective cohort study.
General vs. Regional Anesthesia for Arth.author: Oh TK, Song IA
General vs. Regional Anesthesia for Arth.abstract_summary: This large, nationwide retrospective cohort study from South Korea compared outcomes of regional anesthesia (RA) versus general anesthesia (GA) for total joint arthroplasty. After propensity score matching, the RA group showed significantly lower 30-day and 90-day mortality rates compared to the GA group. However, there was no significant difference in the rate of total postoperative complications between the two anesthesia types.

Imaging for Regional Anesthesia.title: Pericapsular nerve group block: a 3D CT scan imaging study to determine the spread of injectate.
Imaging for Regional Anesthesia.author: Balocco AL, Gautier N, Van Boxstael S, Lopez AM, Carella M, Corten K, Sala-Blanch X, Hadzic A, Gautier PE
Imaging for Regional Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This study used 3D CT imaging to investigate the spread of injectate after a pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block in patients undergoing hip surgery. The imaging revealed that the injectate was mainly confined to the iliacus and psoas muscles, with minimal spread to the hip capsule and no spread towards the obturator nerve. These findings suggest the PENG block's analgesic effect is likely due to blocking femoral nerve branches within the iliopsoas muscle.

Education and Technology in Regional Ane.title: Training and assessment of skills in neuraxial space access: a scoping review of educational approaches to lumbar puncture, epidural anaesthesia, and spinal anaesthesia.
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.author: Nielsen MS, Ilkjaer FV, Grejs AM, Nielsen AB, Konge L, Brochner AC
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.abstract_summary: This scoping review analyzed 99 studies on training and assessment for neuraxial procedures like lumbar puncture and spinal/epidural anesthesia. The review found that while simulation-based training consistently enhances skills and confidence, the overall methodological quality of the studies is low. The authors call for more high-quality research, particularly studies linking training methods to patient outcomes, to develop standardized educational recommendations.

Education and Technology in Regional Ane.title: Using AI chatbots as clinical decision support for regional anesthesia: is the new era of "e-Consults" ready for primetime?
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.author: Corpman D, Auyong DB, Walters D, Gray A
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.abstract_summary: This pilot study evaluated the performance of four popular AI-based chatbots as clinical decision support tools for regional anesthesiology. When prompted with both basic and complex clinical scenarios, all four platforms demonstrated weaknesses in clinical judgment, thoroughness, and rationale. The study concludes that current large language models are not yet ready to reliably assist in clinical decision-making for regional anesthesia.

Education and Technology in Regional Ane.title: The History of Ultrasound-guided Regional Anesthesia.
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.author: Marhofer P, Kapral S
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.abstract_summary: This article revisits the classic 1994 paper by Kapral et al., which was the first to describe an ultrasound-guided technique for regional anesthesia. The authors recount the initial skepticism and subsequent paradigm shift that ultrasound guidance brought to the field. It traces the three-decade journey of research and education that has made ultrasound-guided regional anesthesia a global standard of care.

Education and Technology in Regional Ane.title: Aspiring to mastery clinical skills learning in regional anaesthesia.
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.author: Marshall S, Eppich W
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.abstract_summary: This article discusses the principles of mastery learning as an effective approach for training novices in complex technical skills like regional anesthesia. It explains the theoretical basis of a mastery learning program, which aims to achieve a high level of performance through structured practice. The authors also consider how emerging technologies may influence the future of skill acquisition in this field.

Education and Technology in Regional Ane.title: Artificial intelligence and regional anesthesiology education curriculum development: navigating the digital noise.
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.author: Schroeder KM, Elkassabany N
Education and Technology in Regional Ane.abstract_summary: This article explores the potential of artificial intelligence (AI), particularly large language models, to transform curriculum development in regional anesthesiology education. It suggests that AI can help create targeted and individualized learning content for diverse learners, though it has not yet been widely evaluated for this purpose. The authors emphasize the need to consider how to best deploy and monitor this technology to ensure optimal and safe implementation in medical education.

Infection Control Guidelines.title: ASRA Pain Medicine consensus practice infection control guidelines for regional anesthesia and pain medicine.
Infection Control Guidelines.author: Provenzano DA, Hanes M, Hunt C, Benzon HT, Grider JS, Cawcutt K, Doshi TL, Hayek S, Hoelzer B, Johnson RL, Kalagara H, Kopp S, Loftus RW, Macfarlane AJR, Nagpal AS, Neuman SA, Pawa A, Pearson ACS, Pilitsis J, Sivanesan E, Sondekoppam RV, Van Zundert J, Narouze S
Infection Control Guidelines.abstract_summary: This paper presents evidence-based guidelines on infection control for regional anesthesia and interventional pain procedures, commissioned by the American Society of Regional Anesthesia and Pain Medicine (ASRA). Using a modified Delphi method, the guidelines provide consensus recommendations on risk mitigation, diagnosis, and treatment of infectious complications. The recommendations cover aspects from preoperative patient assessment and sterile technique to postoperative management, intended to serve as a multidisciplinary guide for clinical practice.

Sensory-Selective Nerve Blockade.title: Sensory-selective peripheral and neuraxial nerve blockade with 2',6'-pipecolylxylidine.
Sensory-Selective Nerve Blockade.author: Ostertag-Hill CA, Chen S, Xue T, Shao R, Torre M, Bin F, Vahedi Z, Chen L, Staffa SJ, Zheng Y, Kohane DS
Sensory-Selective Nerve Blockade.abstract_summary: This study investigated the local anesthetic properties of 2',6'-pipecolylxylidine (PPX), a metabolite of amino-amide local anesthetics. In rat models, PPX provided significant sensory-selective nerve blockade at both the sciatic nerve and intrathecal levels, without causing motor block. The study also found that PPX has a favorable safety profile compared to ropivacaine, suggesting its potential as a major advance in pain management.

Fluid Responsiveness Assessment.title: Context-specific clinical applicability of the end-expiratory occlusion test to predict fluid responsiveness in mechanically ventilated patients: A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Fluid Responsiveness Assessment.author: Mulder MP, Potters JW, van Loon LM, Rumindo K, Hallback M, Maksuti E, Donker DW, Diez C
Fluid Responsiveness Assessment.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis evaluated the end-expiratory occlusion test (EEOT) for predicting fluid responsiveness in 24 studies. The EEOT showed acceptable performance overall, particularly in the ICU, but its utility was reduced in the operating room. The study identified clinical context and monitoring methods as significant sources of heterogeneity, highlighting the need for context-specific fluid responsiveness assessments.

Intraoperative Fluid Management Protocol.title: A dynamic elastance-based protocol to guide intra-operative fluid management in major abdominal surgery: A randomised clinical trial.
Intraoperative Fluid Management Protocol.author: Russo A, Aceto P, Cascarano L, Menga LS, Romano B, Carelli S, Console E, Pugliese F, Cambise C, Fiorillo C, Alfieri S, Antonelli M, Sollazzi L, Dell'Anna AM
Intraoperative Fluid Management Protocol.abstract_summary: This randomized trial tested a protocol using dynamic arterial elastance (Ea_dyn) to guide blood pressure management during major abdominal surgery. Compared to a standard protocol based on stroke volume variation, the Ea_dyn protocol did not reduce postoperative lactate levels but was associated with significantly less fluid administration and increased postoperative oxygen consumption. The findings suggest this approach may allow for a more restrictive fluid strategy.

Postoperative Iron Therapy.title: The use of iron after surgery: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Postoperative Iron Therapy.author: Lim J, Joo J, MacLean B, Richards T
Postoperative Iron Therapy.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis evaluated the efficacy of postoperative iron therapy for treating anemia after major surgery. Analysis of 15 randomized controlled trials revealed that intravenous iron administered within 30 days of surgery effectively increased hemoglobin levels. In contrast, oral iron therapy showed no significant benefit, suggesting IV iron is the preferred route for postoperative iron repletion.

Transfusion Prediction Models.title: Development and validation of a predictive model for transfusion in major abdominal surgery: a multicentre retrospective study.
Transfusion Prediction Models.author: Sim JH, Oh AR, Kim S, Park YS, Ha S, Kim JU
Transfusion Prediction Models.abstract_summary: This study developed and validated a nomogram to predict the need for intraoperative red blood cell (RBC) transfusion during major abdominal surgery. The model, which incorporates seven common preoperative variables like age, ASA status, and hemoglobin, demonstrated good predictive ability (C-statistic >0.84) in both development and external validation cohorts. This tool can help systematically assess transfusion risk and improve blood resource management.

Peripartum Anesthesia for Pregnant Patie.title: Diabetes Mellitus in Pregnancy: Implications for Obstetric Anesthesia.
Peripartum Anesthesia for Pregnant Patie.author: Rogers WK, Chugaieva I, Moheet A, Wernimont SA
Peripartum Anesthesia for Pregnant Patie.abstract_summary: This review discusses the anesthetic implications of diabetes during pregnancy. It covers peripartum insulin management, the use of continuous glucose monitors and insulin pumps, and the recognition and management of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis.

Obstetric Anesthesia Workforce and Pract.title: Obstetric Anesthesia Workforce Survey: Forty-year Update.
Obstetric Anesthesia Workforce and Pract.author: Bucklin BA, Hawkins JL, Asdigian NL, Kennerley V, Pattee J, Traynor AJ
Obstetric Anesthesia Workforce and Pract.abstract_summary: This 40-year update of the Obstetric Anesthesia Workforce Survey reveals significant changes in U.S. practice, including a 50% decrease in hospitals providing obstetric care. Despite this, access to neuraxial labor analgesia has dramatically increased to a weighted rate of 84%. The survey also highlights differences between academic and nonacademic practices, providing a broad overview of contemporary obstetric anesthesia services.

Cardiopulmonary Assessment in Preeclamps.title: Prevalence of Point-of-Care Ultrasound Abnormalities and Raised Serum NT-proBNP in Early-Onset Preeclampsia.
Cardiopulmonary Assessment in Preeclamps.author: Fantin RL, Uys F, Schuetz T, Flint M, Lombard CJ, Matjila MJ, Osman A, Swanevelder JL, Dyer RA, Ortner CM
Cardiopulmonary Assessment in Preeclamps.abstract_summary: This study used point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) and biomarkers to assess cardiopulmonary status in 64 women with early-onset preeclampsia (EOPE). A high prevalence of pulmonary interstitial syndrome (PIS), systolic and diastolic dysfunction, and elevated LVEDP was found. Although elevated NT-proBNP was associated with PIS and elevated LVEDP, its clinical predictive value was limited, and PIS was not associated with elevated LVEDP in this cohort.
