Maternal Cardiovascular Morbidity Predic.title: Development and Validation of a Predictive Model for Maternal Cardiovascular Morbidity Events in Patients With Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy.
Maternal Cardiovascular Morbidity Predic.author: Meng ML, Li Y, Fuller M, Lanners Q, Habib AS, Federspiel JJ, Quist-Nelson J, Shah SH, Pencina M, Boggess K, Krishnamoorthy V, Engelhard M
Maternal Cardiovascular Morbidity Predic.abstract_summary: This study developed and validated a machine learning model to predict acute cardiovascular (CV) events in patients with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP). Using a large healthcare database, a multilabel neural network model predicted CV events during the delivery hospitalization with good classification (AUROC 0.878) and events within one year of delivery with fair classification. Chronic renal disease, cardiac disease, and preeclampsia with severe features were key predictors.

Epidural Analgesia and Maternal Fever.title: Maternal fever, epidural analgesia, and genetics: implications for the neonate.
Epidural Analgesia and Maternal Fever.author: Kearns RJ, Nelson SM, Lucas DN
Epidural Analgesia and Maternal Fever.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses epidural-related maternal fever, a common occurrence affecting 15-25% of laboring women. It notes that the underlying mechanisms are still unclear and highlights the clinical challenge of distinguishing it from infectious fever. The authors emphasize that despite the fever risk, there is no strong evidence of harm to the newborn, and women should be supported in their choice of pain relief.

Postdural Puncture Headache (PDPH) Treat.title: No effect of tetracosactide for treatment of postdural puncture headaches in parturient women: a double-blind randomised controlled clinical trial.
Postdural Puncture Headache (PDPH) Treat.author: Dziadzko M, Bouvet L, Steer N, Depaulis C, Pradat P, Joubert F, Lalande L, Chassard D, Aubrun F
Postdural Puncture Headache (PDPH) Treat.abstract_summary: This randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial investigated the efficacy of tetracosactide, a synthetic ACTH analogue, for treating postdural puncture headache (PDPH) in postpartum patients. The study was terminated early for futility after an interim analysis of 44 patients showed no significant difference in the need for an epidural blood patch between the treatment and placebo groups. The authors conclude that ACTH analogues should not be used for this indication.

Practical Guidelines for Pediatric Regio.title: Pediatric Regional Anesthesia: A Practical Guideline for Daily Clinical Practice.
Practical Guidelines for Pediatric Regio.author: Marhofer P, Zadrazil M, Opfermann PL
Practical Guidelines for Pediatric Regio.abstract_summary: This review summarizes state-of-the-art information on pediatric regional anesthesia, highlighting its benefits for pain control and avoiding mechanical ventilation in children. It provides a practical guide for implementing various central and peripheral nerve block techniques in daily clinical practice. The authors emphasize the need for specialized knowledge of anatomy and technique selection.

Preoperative Anemia and Transfusion in N.title: Association between preoperative anaemia, transfusion, and outcomes in children undergoing noncardiac surgery.
Preoperative Anemia and Transfusion in N.author: McCormack G, Faraoni D, DiNardo JA, Goobie SM
Preoperative Anemia and Transfusion in N.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the incidence of preoperative anemia and transfusion in children undergoing noncardiac surgery over 11 years. It found that both anemia and transfusion rates remained stable. The combination of anemia and transfusion was associated with a significant increase in 30-day mortality and postoperative complications.

Remimazolam Pharmacokinetics and Pharmac.title: Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics of Remimazolam for Procedural Sedation in Children and Adolescents.
Remimazolam Pharmacokinetics and Pharmac.author: Colin PJ, Bichajian LH, Curt VR, Koomen JV, Stohr T, Struys MMRF, Mason KP
Remimazolam Pharmacokinetics and Pharmac.abstract_summary: This study analyzed the pharmacokinetics (PK) and pharmacodynamics (PD) of remimazolam for procedural sedation in children aged 6 to 18. The findings indicate that the PK of remimazolam in children differs from adults, even after size correction. The study suggests that the current dosing regimen is suboptimal and proposes a modified, higher per-kilogram dose to achieve effective sedation.

Sugammadex for Neuromuscular Blockade Re.title: Sugammadex for Reversal of Neuromuscular Blockade in Neonates and Infants Less than 2 Years Old: Results from a Phase IV Randomized Clinical Trial.
Sugammadex for Neuromuscular Blockade Re.author: Mensah-Osman E, Mukai Y, Wang A, Matuszczak M, Saldien V, Leibensperger H, Speek M, Locco A, Wrishko R, Gee A, Herring WJ
Sugammadex for Neuromuscular Blockade Re.abstract_summary: This Phase IV clinical trial evaluated the efficacy and safety of sugammadex for neuromuscular blockade (NMB) reversal in children under 2 years old. The study found that 2 mg/kg sugammadex reversed moderate NMB significantly faster than neostigmine. A 4 mg/kg dose rapidly reversed deep NMB, and both doses were well-tolerated in this young pediatric population.

Sugammadex for Neuromuscular Blockade Re.title: Ultrasonographic assessment of sugammadex-enhanced early recovery of diaphragmatic function in children: A randomised double-blind controlled trial.
Sugammadex for Neuromuscular Blockade Re.author: Park JB, Kim TW, Ji SH, Jang YE, Kim EH, Kim JT, Kim HS, Lee JH
Sugammadex for Neuromuscular Blockade Re.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial compared the effects of sugammadex and neostigmine on diaphragmatic function and atelectasis in children aged 2-7. Ultrasound assessment showed that sugammadex led to significantly faster recovery of diaphragmatic excursion and thickening fraction immediately after extubation compared to neostigmine. However, this early diaphragmatic recovery did not translate into a significant reduction in postoperative atelectasis.

Honey for Post-Tonsillectomy Pain Manage.title: Impact of honey on post-tonsillectomy pain in children (BEE PAIN FREE Trial): a multicentre, double-blind, randomised controlled trial.
Honey for Post-Tonsillectomy Pain Manage.author: Sommerfield D, Sommerfield A, Evans D, Hauser N, Vijayasekaran S, Bumbak P, Herbert H, Locher C, Lim LY, Khan RN, von Ungern-Sternberg BS
Honey for Post-Tonsillectomy Pain Manage.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial investigated whether honey could improve recovery in children after tonsillectomy. Four hundred children were randomized to receive standard care, Marri honey, Manuka honey, or a placebo. The study found that taking honey two to three times a day did not significantly improve postoperative pain scores or reduce the need for analgesics compared to standard treatment.

Fibrinogen Concentrate vs. Cryoprecipita.title: Effect of In Vivo Administration of Fibrinogen Concentrate Versus Cryoprecipitate on Ex Vivo Clot Degradation in Neonates Undergoing Cardiac Surgery.
Fibrinogen Concentrate vs. Cryoprecipita.author: Downey LA, Moiseiwitsch N, Nellenbach K, Xiang Y, Brown AC, Guzzetta NA
Fibrinogen Concentrate vs. Cryoprecipita.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared fibrinogen concentrate to cryoprecipitate for hemostasis in neonates after cardiac surgery. Patients receiving fibrinogen concentrate had significantly fewer post-CPB blood transfusions and similar perioperative clot degradation compared to the cryoprecipitate group, with no increase in adverse events. The findings suggest that fibrinogen concentrate can adequately restore hemostasis and reduce transfusion needs in this high-risk population.

Remimazolam for Sedation in Congenital H.title: Remimazolam for successful sedation in children with left-to-right shunt congenital heart disease: An up-and-down sequential allocation trial.
Remimazolam for Sedation in Congenital H.author: Jin M, Lin H, Qiu L, Xu H, Zhang H, Hou S
Remimazolam for Sedation in Congenital H.abstract_summary: This study used an up-and-down sequential allocation method to determine the effective dose (ED50 and ED95) of remimazolam for successful sedation in children aged 1-6 with left-to-right shunt congenital heart disease. The ED50 was found to be 0.209 mg/kg for infants and approximately 0.26 mg/kg for toddlers and preschool children. The drug was well-tolerated, providing guidance for preoperative sedation in this specific patient group.

Pediatric Postoperative Quality of Recov.title: Development of the Pediatric Scale for Quality of Recovery (PedSQoR).
Pediatric Postoperative Quality of Recov.author: Graydon C, Stricker PA, Kelleher S, Cravero J, Karim N, Muhly WT, Lee-Archer P
Pediatric Postoperative Quality of Recov.abstract_summary: This study describes the development of the Pediatric Scale for Quality of Recovery (PedSQoR), a new tool for assessing recovery in children after surgery. Using a mixed-methods approach including literature review, expert panels, and patient/family interviews, a 50-item questionnaire was developed and then refined to a 20-item scale. The final PedSQoR provides a holistic, patient-centered measure of physical and psychological recovery.

Developmental Anesthetic Neurotoxicity a.title: Gut Microbiota Influences Developmental Anesthetic Neurotoxicity in Neonatal Rats.
Developmental Anesthetic Neurotoxicity a.author: Chaki T, Horiguchi Y, Tachibana S, Sato S, Hirahata T, Nishihara N, Kii N, Yoshikawa Y, Hayamizu K, Yamakage M
Developmental Anesthetic Neurotoxicity a.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of gut microbiota in sevoflurane-induced developmental neurotoxicity in neonatal rats. Repeated sevoflurane exposure altered the gut microbiota and impaired spatial learning. Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) after sevoflurane exposure improved these learning deficits, increased gut butyrate concentration, and suppressed neuroinflammation, suggesting that modulating gut microbiota could be a prophylactic strategy for developmental anesthetic neurotoxicity.

Pediatric Premedication Strategies.title: Optimizing pediatric premedication for general anesthesia: A comprehensive Bayesian network meta-analysis.
Pediatric Premedication Strategies.author: Wegner GRM, Wegner BFM, Cumming HS, de Oliveira HG, Campos LR, da Silva LHD, Ferreira CHO, Miranda AM, Donato AB, do Nascimento TS
Pediatric Premedication Strategies.abstract_summary: This Bayesian network meta-analysis of 69 trials evaluated the most effective premedication strategies for pediatric patients. The analysis showed that combinations of dexmedetomidine, midazolam, and ketamine were most effective for improving acceptance of mask application, parental separation, and IV cannulation. Intranasal administration with shorter premedication times (15-30 min) demonstrated greater efficacy.

Pharmacokinetics in Cardiac Surgery.title: Pharmacokinetics of Methadone in Adult Patients Undergoing Cardiac Surgery With Cardiopulmonary Bypass.
Pharmacokinetics in Cardiac Surgery.author: Salas WE, Cortinez LI, Lopez RA, Rolle A, Elgueta F, Godoy CO, Giordano A, Contreras V, Anderson BJ
Pharmacokinetics in Cardiac Surgery.abstract_summary: This study investigated the pharmacokinetics of intravenous methadone in adult patients undergoing cardiac surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). A significant drop in methadone concentrations was observed during CPB, which was attributed to hemodilution and sequestration in the CPB circuit. The study proposes that a supplementary bolus of 0.05 mg/kg at the end of CPB could compensate for this effect.

Acute Kidney Injury Prevention.title: Perioperative Nitric Oxide Conditioning Reduces Acute Kidney Injury in Cardiac Surgery Patients with Chronic Kidney Disease (the DEFENDER Trial): A Randomized Controlled Trial.
Acute Kidney Injury Prevention.author: Kamenshchikov NO, Tyo MA, Berra L, Kravchenko IV, Kozlov BN, Gusakova AM, Podoksenov YK
Acute Kidney Injury Prevention.abstract_summary: The DEFENDER trial, a randomized controlled study, evaluated the effect of perioperative nitric oxide (NO) administration in cardiac surgery patients with chronic kidney disease. The results showed that NO administration significantly reduced the incidence of postoperative acute kidney injury (AKI) compared to the control group (23.5% vs. 39.7%). NO was also found to be safe and slowed the progression of renal dysfunction at six months.

Cardiopulmonary Bypass Management.title: Effects of increased cardiopulmonary bypass pump flow on renal filtration, perfusion, oxygenation and tubular injury in cardiac surgical patients - a randomized controlled trial.
Cardiopulmonary Bypass Management.author: Wijk J, Cordefeldt-Keiller A, Bragadottir G, Redfors B, Ricksten SE, Lannemyr L
Cardiopulmonary Bypass Management.abstract_summary: This randomized trial investigated whether a higher cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) flow rate improves renal outcomes in cardiac surgery patients. The high-flow group (2.9 L/min/m2) showed an improved glomerular filtration rate during CPB and less postoperative tubular injury compared to the standard-flow group (2.4 L/min/m2). These benefits occurred without detectable changes in renal blood flow or oxygenation, suggesting improved renal function with higher CPB flow.

Mortality Risk Prediction Models.title: Development and External Validation of a Novel In-hospital Mortality Model after Pediatric Congenital Heart Surgery: A Multicenter Retrospective Cohort Study.
Mortality Risk Prediction Models.author: Tong C, Li Q, Du X, Shan M, Zhang Y, Wu H, Shen Z, Xu Z, Ge X, Cai S, Fu X, Zhang K, Zhang H, Li S, Miao C, Zheng J
Mortality Risk Prediction Models.abstract_summary: This study tested traditional mortality risk models (ABC, RACHS-1, STAT) in a large Chinese cohort of pediatric congenital heart surgery patients and found them to be only moderately effective. A novel model was developed and validated, incorporating six variables including STAT categories and preoperative covariates. This new model demonstrated superior performance and can serve as a more effective tool for predicting in-hospital mortality in this specific setting.

Perioperative Cardiac Arrest.title: Perioperative cardiac arrest requiring admission to intensive care units in Japan: epidemiological differences between emergency and elective surgery.
Perioperative Cardiac Arrest.author: Anezaki H, Aoki Y, Kato H, Nakajima M, KaszynskiRH, Suzuki K, Yamaguchi T, Naruse S, Kimura T, Mimuro S, Nakajima Y
Perioperative Cardiac Arrest.abstract_summary: This nationwide study in Japan investigated the epidemiology of perioperative cardiac arrest, finding a much higher incidence in emergency surgery (1.74%) compared to elective surgery (0.17%). The leading etiologies also differed, with acute aortic syndrome dominating in emergencies and valvular heart disease in elective cases. In-hospital mortality was significantly higher after emergency surgery (46.2% vs 15.8%), highlighting major differences in risk and outcomes between the two settings.

Vasoplegia Treatment.title: Hydroxocobalamin for vasoplegia in cardiac surgery: a retrospective cohort analysis.
Vasoplegia Treatment.author: Zakaria L, Shah K, Yang D, Kelava M, Elgharably H, Khanna AK, Ahuja S, Hohlfelder B, Alfirevic A, Duncan AE, Skubas NJ, Sessler DI
Vasoplegia Treatment.abstract_summary: This retrospective propensity-matched cohort study evaluated the use of hydroxocobalamin for vasoplegia after cardiac surgery. The study found that hydroxocobalamin administration was associated with a significant reduction in vasopressor requirements over the first 24 hours compared to the control group. However, there was no difference in a composite of in-hospital complications, indicating a need for robust trials to determine clinical benefit.

ROTEM Reference Ranges.title: Pre-operative reference ranges for ROTEM((R)) sigma in patients undergoing cardiac surgery: a secondary analysis of two prospective trial cohorts.
ROTEM Reference Ranges.author: van Haeren MMT, Brouwers M, Schenk J, Breel JS, Noteboom SH, Kho E, Eberl S, Veelo DP, Vlaar APJ, Muller MCA, Hermanns H
ROTEM Reference Ranges.abstract_summary: This study established preoperative ROTEM sigma reference ranges for adult cardiac surgery patients and found significant differences compared to the manufacturer's ranges derived from healthy volunteers. For example, EXTEM and FIBTEM clot firmness limits were higher. While female patients showed a slightly more hypercoagulable profile than males, the overall reference ranges were similar, suggesting the need for cardiovascular-specific, but not sex- or age-specific, ROTEM ranges.

Ventilation Strategies and Outcomes.title: Evaluation of the potential for lung recruitment with the Recruitment-to-Inflation ratio during general anesthesia.
Ventilation Strategies and Outcomes.author: Rosa T, Menga LS, Mastropietro C, Settanni D, Russo A, Frassanito L, Cascarano L, Catarci S, Delle Cese L, Zanfini BA, Scaramuzzo G, Dell'Anna AM, Spadaro S, Antonelli M, Grieco DL
Ventilation Strategies and Outcomes.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the recruitment-to-inflation ratio (R/I) as a tool to assess lung recruitability during general anesthesia for open abdominal surgery. The R/I, measured non-invasively, correlated well with recruitment measured by gas dilution and electrical impedance tomography. Patients with a higher R/I (>0.40) required higher PEEP levels to optimize lung mechanics, suggesting R/I can help individualize ventilator settings to favor less injurious ventilation.

Ventilation Strategies and Outcomes.title: Intra-operative ventilation strategies and their impact on clinical outcomes: a systematic review and network meta-analysis of randomised trials.
Ventilation Strategies and Outcomes.author: Jivraj NK, Lakbar I, Sadeghirad B, Muller MM, Sohn SY, Peel JK, Jaffer A, Phoophiboon V, Trivedi V, Chaudhuri D, Lu C, Liu Y, Giammarioli B, Einav S, Burns KEA
Ventilation Strategies and Outcomes.abstract_summary: This systematic review and network meta-analysis of 51 randomized trials evaluated intra-operative ventilation strategies to prevent postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs). The results show that low tidal volume ventilation, combined with various PEEP levels, likely reduces the risk of PPCs compared to high tidal volume with zero PEEP. The study highlights the need for better implementation of lung-protective ventilation strategies in clinical practice.

Postoperative Pulmonary Complications in.title: Impact of early high flow nasal oxygen on diaphragmatic function and pulmonary complications after thoracic surgery: A randomized clinical trial.
Postoperative Pulmonary Complications in.author: Fogagnolo A, Grasso S, Dres M, Azzolina D, Dalla Corte F, Dolci G, Tamburini N, De Paoli G, Murgolo F, Pedarzani E, Andalo A; Volta CA, Savino S
Postoperative Pulmonary Complications in.abstract_summary: This randomized trial investigated whether early high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) oxygen therapy could reduce diaphragmatic dysfunction and postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) after thoracic surgery. Overall, HFNC did not decrease the rate of these complications compared to conventional oxygen therapy. However, a post-hoc analysis suggested that in the subgroup of patients who did develop diaphragmatic dysfunction, HFNC may help mitigate the risk of PPCs.

Prevention of Postoperative Neurocogniti.title: Effect of perioperative autonomic nervous system imbalance on surgical outcomes: a systematic literature review.
Prevention of Postoperative Neurocogniti.author: Pan WT, Ji MH, Ma D, Yang JJ
Prevention of Postoperative Neurocogniti.abstract_summary: This systematic review explores how perioperative autonomic nervous system (ANS) imbalance, marked by sympathetic hyperactivation, contributes to adverse surgical outcomes like infections and neurocognitive decline. It discusses how surgical stress, anesthesia, and pain disrupt ANS balance and reviews evidence for therapeutic strategies such as dexmedetomidine and beta-blockers. The authors highlight that modulating the ANS is a promising approach to mitigate postoperative complications.

Prevention of Postoperative Neurocogniti.title: Patterns of prevention effectiveness in postoperative neurocognitive disorder and delayed neurocognitive recovery research: a systematic review with meta-regression of randomised trials.
Prevention of Postoperative Neurocogniti.author: Lahiri NK, Vuckovic N, Sidhu AS, Li J, Sun Y, Naiken S, Curtis SJ, Bisch E, Bolda R, Nagra PS, Mann G, Gonzales AE, Smith L, Anderson BP, Liu Z, Adams DC, Meng L
Prevention of Postoperative Neurocogniti.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-regression analyzed 187 trials on preventing postoperative neurocognitive disorder (pNCD/dNCR). The study found that trial characteristics, such as geographic location and study design, significantly influenced the reported effectiveness of interventions. Dexmedetomidine was the most studied agent with potential benefits, though the evidence certainty was very low.

Central Amygdala Neurons in Anesthesia-I.title: General Anesthesia-activated Neurons in the Central Amygdala Mediate Antinociception: Distinct Roles in Acute versus Chronic Phases of Nerve Injury.
Central Amygdala Neurons in Anesthesia-I.author: Zhao J, Furutani K, McGinnis A, Mathew JP, Wang F, Ji RR
Central Amygdala Neurons in Anesthesia-I.abstract_summary: This study investigated a specific group of neurons in the central amygdala (CeA) that are activated by general anesthesia and mediate antinociception. Using mouse models, researchers found that activating these neurons effectively reduced pain in the acute phase after nerve injury but had a diminished effect in the chronic phase. This change was linked to a downregulation of the KCC2 transporter, highlighting a potential mechanism for the transition to chronic pain.

Anesthetic Amnesia Mechanisms.title: Anesthetic Amnesia: The Forgotten Importance of Forgetting?
Anesthetic Amnesia Mechanisms.author: Pryor KO, Jiang Y, Sleigh JW
Anesthetic Amnesia Mechanisms.abstract_summary: This article argues that the study of anesthetic-induced amnesia has been overshadowed by research on hypnosis, despite its critical importance. The authors note that consciousness may not be entirely absent during anesthesia, with amnesia creating an illusion of unconsciousness. They highlight the need for better understanding of amnestic mechanisms, especially since there is no reliable real-time biomarker for amnesia, and surgical memories can contribute to post-traumatic stress symptoms.

Cerebrovascular Compliance and Hypertens.title: Cerebral Blood Flow Under Pressure: Investigating Cerebrovascular Compliance with Phase Contrast Magnetic Resonance Imaging During Induced Hypertension.
Cerebrovascular Compliance and Hypertens.author: Osterlind J, Birnefeld J, Eklund A, Hultin M, Wahlin A, Holmlund P, Zarrinkoob L
Cerebrovascular Compliance and Hypertens.abstract_summary: This study used phase-contrast MRI to assess cerebrovascular compliance in healthy adults during norepinephrine-induced hypertension. The results showed that cerebral arteries significantly enhanced their compliance in response to elevated blood pressure, an adaptive response not seen in systemic arteries. This suggests a protective mechanism in the brain to buffer flow dynamics and protect the microcirculation during periods of hypertension.

Neuroprotective Treatments for Hypoxic-I.title: Xenon and Argon as Neuroprotective Treatments for Perinatal Hypoxic-Ischemic Brain Injury: A Preclinical Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.
Neuroprotective Treatments for Hypoxic-I.author: Barros M, Liang M, Iannucci N, Dickinson R
Neuroprotective Treatments for Hypoxic-I.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 21 preclinical studies evaluated xenon and argon as neuroprotective treatments for perinatal hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). The analysis found that both gases showed significant neuroprotective efficacy in animal models. Argon demonstrated a greater summary effect than xenon, providing strong evidence to support further investigation of both agents for treating HIE.

Procedural Sedation in Pediatrics.title: Remimazolam for successful sedation in children with left-to-right shunt congenital heart disease: An up-and-down sequential allocation trial.
Procedural Sedation in Pediatrics.author: Jin M, Lin H, Qiu L, Xu H, Zhang H, Hou S
Procedural Sedation in Pediatrics.abstract_summary: This study used an up-and-down sequential allocation method to determine the effective dose (ED50 and ED95) of remimazolam for successful sedation in children aged 1-6 with left-to-right shunt congenital heart disease. The ED50 was found to be 0.209 mg/kg for infants and approximately 0.26 mg/kg for toddlers and preschool children. The drug was well-tolerated, providing guidance for preoperative sedation in this specific patient group.

Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) P.title: The Story of Enhancing Recovery after Surgery.
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) P.author: Kehlet H
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) P.abstract_summary: This article reviews the principles of Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS). It explains how major surgery induces a stress response and that a multimodal approach, rather than single interventions, is key to reducing complications, improving recovery, and lowering costs.

Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) P.title: Association Between Two Muscle-Related Parameters and Postoperative Complications in Patients Undergoing Colorectal Tumor Resection Surgery.
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) P.author: Gao D, Miao H, Sheng W, Liu L, Wang R, Shi H, Li T
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) P.abstract_summary: This retrospective study investigated the link between preoperative muscle mass (L3 SMI) and muscle density (HUAC) with postoperative complications in colorectal surgery patients. The study found that myosteatosis (low muscle density) was significantly associated with a higher incidence of postoperative complications, particularly severe ones. This suggests that preoperative CT-based muscle assessment could help identify high-risk patients.

Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) P.title: Quality of patient-centred recovery trajectories after different types of surgery: a prospective cohort study.
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) P.author: Myles PS, Phillips B, Robertshaw S, Haughney H, Houle TT, Rowland R, Johnson D, Wallace S
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) P.abstract_summary: This prospective study tracked patient recovery trajectories up to 90 days after surgery using the QoR-15 score and days alive and at home (DAH30). Recovery varied significantly based on the magnitude of the surgery (gastroscopy vs. intermediate vs. cardiac), with lower nadir scores and DAH30 in more extensive procedures. The study demonstrates the utility of these patient-centered outcomes for measuring recovery and highlights that patients value frequent follow-up.

Opioid-Free Anesthesia.title: Effects of an opioid-free care pathway vs. opioid-based standard care on postoperative pain and postoperative quality of recovery after laparoscopic bariatric surgery: A multicentre randomised controlled trial.
Opioid-Free Anesthesia.author: Olausson A, Jildenstal P, Andrell P, Angelini E, Stenberg E, Wallenius V, Ohrstrom H, Thorn SE, Wolf A
Opioid-Free Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial compared an opioid-free care pathway (including intraoperative OFA and postoperative TENS) to standard opioid-based care for patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The study found no difference in postoperative pain or quality of recovery between the groups. However, the opioid-free pathway significantly reduced in-hospital opioid consumption.

GDF-15 as a Biomarker for Postoperative.title: Association between plasma growth differentiation factor-15 and postoperative nausea and vomiting incidence and severity: a secondary analysis of a randomised trial.
GDF-15 as a Biomarker for Postoperative.author: Mai Y, Zhang S, Huang Q, Liang C, Shi J, Zheng J, Lv K, Liu H, Yang X, Zhao Y
GDF-15 as a Biomarker for Postoperative.abstract_summary: This study investigated the link between plasma growth differentiation factor-15 (GDF-15) and postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) in patients undergoing laparoscopic gastrointestinal surgery. The results showed that lower preoperative GDF-15 concentrations were significantly associated with a higher risk of developing PONV. This suggests GDF-15 could be a potential biomarker to help identify at-risk patients.

Ketamine for Postsurgical Pain.title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Intraoperative Ketamine for Acute Postsurgical Pain after Breast Cancer Surgery: The Moderating Effect of Baseline Temporal Summation of Pain.
Ketamine for Postsurgical Pain.author: Wilson JM, Gokul S, Franqueiro AR, Rosado E, Yong RJ, Edwards RR, Schreiber KL
Ketamine for Postsurgical Pain.abstract_summary: This randomized trial investigated the effect of intraoperative ketamine on postoperative pain after breast surgery. Overall, ketamine showed no analgesic benefit over placebo in the 225-patient cohort. However, an exploratory analysis suggested that patients with higher baseline temporal summation of pain (a marker of central sensitization) may derive an analgesic benefit from ketamine, highlighting the potential for personalized pain management.

Gabapentin for Major Surgery.title: Gabapentin for pain management following major surgery: a placebo controlled, double blind, randomized clinical trial (The GAP Study).
Gabapentin for Major Surgery.author: Baos S, Lui M, Walker-Smith T, Pufulete M, Messenger D, Abbadi R, Batchelor T, Casali G, Edwards M, Goddard N, Abu Hilal M, Alzetani A, Vaida M, Martinovsky P, Saravanan P, Cook T, Malhotra R, Simpson A, Little R, Wordsworth S, Stokes E, Eu-Hem JJ, Reeves B, Culliford L, Collett L, Maishman R, Chauhan N, McCullagh L, McKeon H, Abbs S, Lamb J, Gilbert A, Hughes C, Wynick D, Angelini G, Grocott M, Gibbison B, Rogers CA
Gabapentin for Major Surgery.abstract_summary: The GAP Study, a large multicenter randomized controlled trial, evaluated the effectiveness of perioperative gabapentin in patients undergoing major cardiac, thoracic, or abdominal surgery. The study found that adding gabapentin to a multimodal analgesic regimen did not reduce the length of hospital stay or the incidence of serious adverse events compared to placebo. These findings challenge the routine use of gabapentin for major surgery.

Post-discharge Digital Health Interventi.title: Post discharge digital health technology interventions in ambulatory surgery: A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Post-discharge Digital Health Interventi.author: Bentsen SB, Stjernberg M, Raeder J, Eide GE, Tvedt MN, Hegland PA
Post-discharge Digital Health Interventi.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of six randomized controlled trials evaluated the effects of post-discharge digital health interventions (DHIs) for ambulatory surgery patients. The meta-analysis found no significant effect of DHIs on postoperative pain or unplanned healthcare encounters. However, individual studies suggested DHIs may reduce some symptoms, lower costs, and improve quality of life, though the overall certainty of evidence was low.

Postoperative Sore Throat Prevention.title: Effect of dexamethasone and lidocaine combination on incidence of post-operative sore throat: A meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.
Postoperative Sore Throat Prevention.author: Ikram J, Ali A, Moeez A, Khan MM, Ubaidullah, Mujeeb A, Ali MA, Tanveer S, Khan MWZ, Zaman B, Syed A, Nadeem MA, Zahid A, Khudirat M, Sawaira, Minear S, Ayad S
Postoperative Sore Throat Prevention.abstract_summary: This meta-analysis of three randomized controlled trials investigated whether combining intravenous dexamethasone and lidocaine is more effective than dexamethasone alone for preventing postoperative sore throat (POST). The combination therapy significantly reduced the incidence of POST. However, trial sequential analysis indicated that the evidence is not yet conclusive, and further trials are needed to confirm these findings.

Psychological Interventions for Postsurg.title: Effectiveness of peri-operative psychological interventions for the reduction of postsurgical pain intensity, depression, anxiety and pain catastrophising: A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Psychological Interventions for Postsurg.author: Castano-Asins JR, Barcelo-Soler A, Royuela-Colomer E, Sanabria-Mazo JP, Garcia V, Neblett R, Bulbena A, Perez-Sola V, Montes-Perez A; Urrutia G, Feliu-Soler A, Luciano JV
Psychological Interventions for Postsurg.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 27 randomized controlled trials evaluated the effectiveness of perioperative psychological interventions on pain-related outcomes. The analysis found that these interventions, particularly CBT delivered by a psychologist, significantly reduced postoperative pain intensity and anxiety compared to usual care. The evidence quality was moderate, but the authors caution that many trials had a high risk of bias.

Oliceridine for Postoperative Pain.title: Oliceridine for postoperative pain and opioid-related complications: The intravenous oliceridine and opioid-related complications (VOLITION) prospective cohort study.
Oliceridine for Postoperative Pain.author: Sessler DI, Ayad S, Bakal O, Disher NS, Duran JA, Weingarten TN, Dahan A; Demitrack MA, Kim J, Khanna AK
Oliceridine for Postoperative Pain.abstract_summary: The VOLITION study prospectively evaluated the use of oliceridine for postoperative pain in 203 patients undergoing major noncardiac surgery. While no life-threatening respiratory events occurred, nearly one-quarter of patients experienced some form of respiratory compromise. A randomized trial is needed to determine if oliceridine offers a better safety profile regarding opioid-related adverse events compared to conventional opioids.

Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.title: Translational control by general control nonderepressible 2 kinase regulates methylglyoxal-induced pain in mice.
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.author: Meyer AR, Garcia G, Mikesell AR, O'Flanagan S, Stucky CL, Campbell ZT
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigates the link between the metabolic byproduct methylglyoxal (MGO), a key factor in diabetic neuropathy, and the integrated stress response (ISR) in pain signaling. Researchers found that MGO activates the ISR via the GCN2 kinase by disrupting ribosome function. In mouse models, both neuronal sensitization and mechanical allodynia caused by MGO were dependent on GCN2, identifying it as a potential new analgesic target for diabetic pain.

Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.title: Autoreactive immunoglobulin G levels and Fc receptor gamma subunit upregulation drive mechanical allodynia after nerve constriction or crush injury.
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.author: Fiore NT, Willcox KF, Grieco AR, Dayani D, Zuberi YA, Heijnen CJ, Grace PM
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study in mice investigated the role of B cell-IgG-Fc-gamma-receptor signaling in mechanical allodynia after different types of peripheral nerve injury. The findings reveal that this pathway is crucial for pain following chronic constriction (CCI) and nerve crush injuries, but not after spared nerve injury (SNI) or spinal nerve ligation. The difference appears to be driven by whether the injury upregulates the Fc receptor gamma subunit in the DRG and spinal cord.

Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.title: Proteomic analysis of isolated nerve terminals from NaV1.9 knockout mice reveals pathways relevant for pain perception.
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.author: Rawat A, Vu DT, Erbacher C, Stigloher C, Uceyler N, Metousis A, Mann M, Briese M, Sendtner M
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study used proteomic analysis to investigate peripheral pain signaling mechanisms by isolating and examining nerve terminals from the footpads of wild-type and NaV1.9 knockout mice. The analysis revealed that nerve terminals are enriched with mitochondria and protein translation machinery, and that NaV1.9 deficiency leads to dysregulation of the MAPK and ERK1/2 pathways. This approach offers a valuable translational model for studying pain mechanisms in human biomaterials.

Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.title: Enhancing clinical translation of analgesics for neuropathic pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis on the role of non-evoked pain assessment in preclinical trials.
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.author: Huerta MA, Roza P, Cisneros E, Alique M, Roza C
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 91 preclinical studies evaluated the efficacy of standard analgesics on non-evoked pain (NEP) in animal models of neuropathic pain. The results showed that the efficacy patterns of drugs like tricyclic antidepressants and gabapentinoids in relieving NEP closely mirrored their clinical performance in humans. The findings underscore the importance of assessing spontaneous pain behaviors in preclinical trials to improve the translation of new analgesics to the clinic.

Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.title: STIM1 functionally couples to transient receptor potential ankyrin 1 contributing to nociception.
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.author: Mei Y, Birla H, Lee BH, Li Z, Rai V, Zhang I, Huo X, Yi A, Zhang Q, Li D, Zhong Y, Wang F, Yasin B, Apai C, Rohacs T, Tao YX, Bekker A, Hu H
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study reveals a novel functional link between the calcium sensor STIM1 and the TRPA1 ion channel in nociception. Researchers found that activation of TRPA1 in the endoplasmic reticulum triggers STIM1, leading to store-operated calcium entry and increased neuronal excitability. This STIM1-TRPA1 coupling plays an important role in sensing cold, chemical, and noxious mechanical stimuli, identifying STIM1 as a new transducer of nociception.

Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.title: Decreased KCC2 expression in the human spinal dorsal horn associated with chronic pain and long-term opioid use.
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.author: Davis OC, Ferland S, Lorenzo LE, Murray-Lawson C, Shiers S, Yousuf MS, Dedek A, Tsai EC, Vines E, Horton P, Cervantes A, Khan T, Funk G, Dussor G, Godin AG, Ferrini F, De Koninck Y, Hildebrand ME, Price TJ
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study provides the first human evidence that the chloride transporter KCC2 is downregulated in the spinal dorsal horn of individuals with chronic pain or long-term opioid use. By examining tissue from organ donors, researchers found profoundly decreased KCC2 membrane expression in these groups. This finding supports the hypothesis that a loss of inhibitory efficacy in the spinal cord contributes to chronic pain in humans and identifies KCC2 as a key therapeutic target.

Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.title: Diminished transient receptor vanilloid 1 on skin nerve fibers in painful bortezomib-induced peripheral neuropathy.
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.author: Jin Y, Aravamudhan A, Cebulla N, Schirmer D, Runau E, Flamm L, Terhorst C, Jahnel L, Guse J, Giordani N, Wieser A, Sodmann A, Blum R, Kittel RJ, Sommer C
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of TRPV1 receptors in bortezomib-induced peripheral neuropathy (BIPN) by examining skin biopsies from patients and healthy volunteers. The results showed a significant decrease in TRPV1 immunoreactivity on small nerve fibers in patients with BIPN, with a greater reduction in those experiencing pain. This diminished TRPV1 expression correlated with reduced thermal sensitivity and higher pain levels, providing new insights into the pathophysiology of painful BIPN.

Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.title: Cortical integration and control of spontaneous neuropathic pain-like behaviour in mice.
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.author: Li Z, Huang X, Ma J, Liu Q, Chen L, Liu X, Qin Q, Yang H, Han R, Li K, Hu R, Yan X, Huang Y, Huang D, Zhou H
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) in spontaneous neuropathic pain using mouse models. Researchers found that cortical hyperactivity in the ACC is a key feature, and that inhibiting this region can alleviate pain-like behavior, while activating it restores pain. These findings highlight the ACC's essential role in processing and modulating non-evoked neuropathic pain.

Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.title: Neurone-satellite glial cell interactions in dorsal root ganglia drive peripheral sensitisation in a mouse burn pain model.
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.author: Zhang R, Zhang N, Chen D, Hu X, Zhang M, Yao M, Zhang Q, Wu S, Zhang X, He Y, Gao F, Xu B, Fang Q
Mechanisms of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study explores the mechanisms of peripheral sensitization in a mouse model of burn pain. It reveals that burn injury triggers CGRP release from sensory neurons, which in turn activates satellite glial cells (SGCs) in the dorsal root ganglia. This neuron-SGC interaction, involving chemokines like CXCL1, enhances neuronal excitability and pain, suggesting that targeting this pathway could be a therapeutic strategy for burn pain.

Interventional Pain Management.title: Pulsed radiofrequency of lumbar dorsal root ganglion versus epidural neuroplasty for lumbar radicular pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
Interventional Pain Management.author: Park JH, Jang JN, Park S, Choi YS, Ryu DK, Miah R, Park S
Interventional Pain Management.abstract_summary: This network meta-analysis of 14 randomized controlled trials compared pulsed radiofrequency (PRF) of the dorsal root ganglion and epidural neuroplasty for treating lumbar radicular pain. While epidural neuroplasty showed a slight advantage over PRF at 3 months, the overall certainty of evidence was low to very low. The study concludes that both interventions may offer comparable long-term outcomes, but highlights the urgent need for direct, high-quality trials to guide treatment selection.

Interventional Pain Management.title: Navigating current controversies in radiofrequency ablation of the genicular nerves for chronic knee pain in osteoarthritis: a daring discourse.
Interventional Pain Management.author: Ferreira-Silva N, Ferreira-Dos-Santos G, Cunat T, Ribeiro-da-Silva T, Peng P
Interventional Pain Management.abstract_summary: This discourse critically analyzes ongoing controversies surrounding radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of genicular nerves for chronic knee osteoarthritis pain. It addresses key debates, including the role of prognostic blocks, optimal nerve targets, guidance techniques (ultrasound vs. fluoroscopy), and the use of RFA after total knee arthroplasty. The paper aims to guide clinical decision-making and stimulate further research to resolve these heterogeneous practices.

Interventional Pain Management.title: To trial or not to trial before peripheral nerve stimulation for chronic pain: a retrospective multicenter comparative analysis of temporary-to-permanent and direct-to-permanent implantation approaches.
Interventional Pain Management.author: D'Souza RS, Yu Y, Singh V, Karri J, Javed S, Her YF, Chai N, Hoffmann C, Warner DO, Hussain N
Interventional Pain Management.abstract_summary: This multicenter retrospective study compared outcomes between patients who underwent a temporary trial before permanent peripheral nerve stimulation (PNS) and those who received a direct-to-permanent implant. The analysis of 130 patients found no significant difference in pain relief, opioid consumption, or adverse events at 6 months between the two approaches. The findings suggest that a temporary trial may not be necessary to achieve successful outcomes with permanent PNS.

Interventional Pain Management.title: Chemical ablation of pericapsular nerve group with 95% ethanol for pain relief and quality of life in patients with hip osteoarthritis: a prospective, double-blinded, randomised, controlled trial.
Interventional Pain Management.author: Reysner M, Reysner T, Kowalski G, Mularski A, Daroszewski P; Wieczorowska-Tobis K
Interventional Pain Management.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial evaluated the efficacy of ultrasound-guided pericapsular nerve group (PENG) neurolysis using 95% ethanol for chronic hip osteoarthritis pain. Compared to a sham procedure, the ethanol neurolysis group experienced significant and long-term pain relief for up to 6 months. This intervention also led to reduced opioid consumption and improved quality of life without neurological deficits.

Interventional Pain Management.title: Clinical study of a micro-implantable pulse generator for the treatment of peripheral neuropathic pain: 3-month and 6-month results from the COMFORT-randomised controlled trial.
Interventional Pain Management.author: Hatheway J, Hersel A, Song J, Engle M, Gutierrez G, Khemlani V; Kapural L, Moore G, Ajakwe R, Trainor D, Hah J, Staats PS, Lynch P; Makous J, Heit G, Kottalgi S, Desai MJ
Interventional Pain Management.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial evaluated a micro-implantable pulse generator for peripheral nerve stimulation (PNS) in treating chronic peripheral pain. At 3 and 6 months, the PNS group showed significantly superior pain reduction (67% and 70% respectively) compared to the control group receiving conventional medical management (6%). The results demonstrate that this micro-IPG is a safe and efficacious treatment for chronic peripheral pain.

Interventional Pain Management.title: Extended reality navigation for pain procedures: a narrative review.
Interventional Pain Management.author: Cho JS, Jotwani R, Chan S, Thaker DM, On JD, Yong RJ, Hao D
Interventional Pain Management.abstract_summary: This narrative review examines the use of extended reality (XR) technology for procedural navigation in pain medicine. Early evidence from 13 studies suggests XR has the potential to improve procedural efficiency and is particularly useful for creating patient-specific navigation plans in cases of difficult anatomy. The review discusses best practices for developing XR systems and their future role in regional anesthesia and pain medicine.

Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.title: Chronic pain is associated with sleep apnea severity but attenuated by intermittent hypoxemia in people using opioids.
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.author: Orr JE, Bosompra NO, Norby B, Velazquez J, Khalaf A, DeYoung P; Schmickl CN, Sands SA, Jain S, He F, Goodin B, Wallace M, Owens RL; Malhotra A
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.abstract_summary: This study examined the relationship between sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) and pain in adults using long-term opioids. The results showed that while worsened SDB severity (higher AHI) was linked to increased pain interference and lower pain tolerance, this effect was attenuated in patients with higher levels of associated hypoxemia. This suggests that for a given AHI, pain symptoms may differ depending on the individual's hypoxic burden.

Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.title: Are adults with chronic pain more likely to develop hypertension than adults without chronic pain? A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.author: Taylor HE, Salf JC, Roper-Marchand CR, Senaratne DNS, Smith BH; Colvin LA, George J
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 23 studies investigated the association between chronic pain (CP) and hypertension (HTN). The pooled analysis showed that people with CP had a 1.66-fold increased odds of having HTN compared to controls. This association was significant for chronic widespread pain and chronic headache, confirming a link between chronic pain and hypertension.

Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.title: Risk of dementia following gabapentin prescription in chronic low back pain patients.
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.author: Eghrari NB, Yazji IH, Yavari B, Van Acker GM, Kim CH
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.abstract_summary: This retrospective cohort study using a large national database examined the association between gabapentin use for chronic low back pain and the risk of dementia. The study found that patients with six or more gabapentin prescriptions had a significantly increased risk of dementia and mild cognitive impairment. The risk was particularly elevated in non-elderly adults (aged 18-64), suggesting a need for cognitive monitoring in patients prescribed gabapentin.

Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.title: Predictive role of central nervous system-driven symptoms in the development of chronic primary pain.
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.author: Trouvin AP, Bailly F
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent study showing that central nervous system-driven symptoms like sleep disturbances and mood disorders often precede the onset of chronic primary pain. This research, based on UK Biobank data, suggests a potential window for early intervention and prevention. It enhances understanding of nociplastic pain mechanisms.

Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.title: Sex-specific genetics underlie increased chronic pain risk in women: genome-wide association studies from the UK Biobank.
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.author: Parisien M, Fillingim M, Tanguay-Sabourin C, Roy M, Vachon-Presseau E; Diatchenko L
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.abstract_summary: This genome-wide association study using UK Biobank data explored the genetic reasons for the higher prevalence of chronic pain in women. The research identified that women have four times more sex-specific causal loci for pain, primarily enriched in brain regions, than men. These genetic factors, particularly related to brain structure, are more often causally linked to chronic pain in women, suggesting a strong genetic underpinning for this sex disparity.

Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.title: Diminished transient receptor vanilloid 1 on skin nerve fibers in painful bortezomib-induced peripheral neuropathy.
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.author: Jin Y, Aravamudhan A, Cebulla N, Schirmer D, Runau E, Flamm L, Terhorst C, Jahnel L, Guse J, Giordani N, Wieser A, Sodmann A, Blum R, Kittel RJ, Sommer C
Chronic Pain and Comorbidities.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of TRPV1 receptors in bortezomib-induced peripheral neuropathy (BIPN) by examining skin biopsies from patients and healthy volunteers. The results showed a significant decrease in TRPV1 immunoreactivity on small nerve fibers in patients with BIPN, with a greater reduction in those experiencing pain. This diminished TRPV1 expression correlated with reduced thermal sensitivity and higher pain levels, providing new insights into the pathophysiology of painful BIPN.

Opioid Use and Management.title: Developing a Wearable Sensor-Based Digital Biomarker of Opioid Dependence.
Opioid Use and Management.author: Carreiro S, Ramanand P, Akram W, Stapp J, Chapman B, Smelson D, Indic P
Opioid Use and Management.abstract_summary: This study aimed to develop a digital biomarker for opioid dependence using wearable sensor data. By monitoring opioid-naive and chronic opioid-using participants with acute pain, researchers developed machine learning models that could distinguish between the two groups with high accuracy (70-90%). The findings suggest that wearable sensor data can detect physiological adaptations to opioid use, potentially offering a novel tool for safer prescribing and monitoring.

Opioid Use and Management.title: Population-based multistate modelling of peritraumatic opioid use among trauma patients from the Norwegian Trauma Registry.
Opioid Use and Management.author: Engel S, Rosseland LA, Smits M, Skurtveit SO, Gran JM, Nordseth T; Roise O, Jacobsen HB
Opioid Use and Management.abstract_summary: This population-based study analyzed opioid use patterns in trauma patients from the Norwegian Trauma Registry. The findings show that most patients with long-term opioid use after injury had a history of pre-injury opioid use, primarily for chronic pain. The study underscores the need for effective non-opioid pain management alternatives.

Opioid Use and Management.title: One-year opioid consumption trajectories among individuals receiving multidisciplinary postsurgical care: a single-center observational study from the Toronto General Hospital Transitional Pain Service.
Opioid Use and Management.author: Page MG, Katz J, Darville R, Gabriel G, Ladha KS, Huang A; Ganty P, Katznelson R, Tamir D, Fiorellino J, Kahn M, Tao L; Slepian M, Wieskopf J, Clarke H
Opioid Use and Management.abstract_summary: This observational study tracked opioid use and pain intensity for one year in high-risk patients enrolled in a Transitional Pain Service (TPS). The results identified three distinct opioid consumption trajectories, all of which decreased over time, with biopsychosocial factors like substance use disorder and psychological distress associated with higher use. The study highlights the heterogeneity of postsurgical recovery and supports the use of personalized, multidisciplinary interventions like TPS.

Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.title: Measurement instruments of pain-related avoidance in chronic pain: a systematic review of psychometric properties.
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.author: Traxler J, Gaggini E, Philips RV, Warny A, Peters ML, Crombez G; Vlaeyen JWS
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.abstract_summary: This systematic review evaluated the psychometric properties of 22 different instruments used to measure pain-related avoidance in adults with chronic pain. After analyzing 140 articles, the review found that while research on internal consistency and construct validity is extensive, high-quality evidence on measurement error and criterion validity is lacking for most tools. Only two versions of the Chronic Pain Coping Inventory met the criteria to be fully recommended for use.

Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.title: Understanding the untreated course of adults with chronic pain seeking psychological intervention: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.author: Morgan Z, Scott A, Bisby MA, Chandra S, Hathway T, Correa AB; Dear BF
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis examined symptom changes in control groups of 52 RCTs where adults with chronic pain were awaiting psychological treatment. The analysis found that over an average control period of 13.5 weeks, participants showed very small but statistically significant improvements in pain and disability, with no significant change in depression or anxiety. These findings suggest that symptoms are relatively stable, not worsening, during short waits for psychologically-based pain management.

Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.title: Silent information regulator sirtuin 1-mediated neuronal excitation-inhibition imbalance in the central amygdala is involved in peripheral nerve injury-induced depression-related behavior in mice.
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.author: Lin JT, Ding XB, Dong W, Wu WF, Lin YW, Zhou CR; Zhang CD, Chen C, Sun YM, Liu Q, Liu YP, Zhou CH, Wu YQ
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of the histone deacetylase SIRT1 in depression-like behavior following peripheral nerve injury in mice. Researchers found that SIRT1 was downregulated in the central amygdala (CeA), leading to an excitation-inhibition imbalance (increased glutamatergic and decreased GABAergic activity). Overexpressing SIRT1 in the CeA corrected this imbalance and alleviated the depression-related behaviors, identifying SIRT1 as a key regulator in this process.

Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.title: Neurophysiological encoding of aversive prediction errors.
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.author: Gopalakrishnan R, Sonneborn C, Baillet S, Machado AG, Wager TD, Roy M
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.abstract_summary: This study used magnetoencephalography (MEG) to investigate the brain signals underlying aversive prediction errors (PEs)—the mismatch between expected and actual pain. The findings indicate that aversive PE signals are rapidly generated in the alpha band (8-12 Hz) by the midbrain, orbitofrontal cortex, and ventrolateral prefrontal cortex around 150 ms after an outcome. This research reveals the fast neurophysiological mechanisms involved in learning to avoid pain.

Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.title: Subjective salience ratings are a reliable proxy for physiological measures of arousal.
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.author: Hadjis GE, Atlas LY, Mouseli P, Sexton CA, McAndrews MP, Moayedi M
Psychological Aspects of Chronic Pain.abstract_summary: This study aimed to determine if subjective salience ratings are a valid proxy for physiological arousal, measured by skin conductance response (SCR), when comparing painful and non-painful stimuli. In 41 healthy adults, there were no differences in SCR between heat pain and electric stimuli that were subjectively matched for salience. The results confirm that subjective ratings are suitable for salience-matching in pain research, which is crucial for isolating pain-specific brain processes.

Pain Assessment and Measurement.title: Immersion in nature through virtual reality attenuates the development and spread of mechanical secondary hyperalgesia: a role for insulo-thalamic effective connectivity.
Pain Assessment and Measurement.author: Medina S, Hughes SW
Pain Assessment and Measurement.abstract_summary: This study investigated the brain mechanisms of nature-based analgesia using immersive virtual reality (VR) in healthy participants with experimentally induced pain sensitization. Immersive nature VR significantly reduced the development and spread of secondary mechanical hyperalgesia compared to a 2D nature video or no intervention. Neuroimaging analysis suggested that these analgesic effects are mediated by insulo-thalamic effective connectivity, likely through top-down endogenous pain-modulating systems.

Pain Assessment and Measurement.title: Evaluating the efficacy of neurokinin-1 (substance P) receptor antagonist CP-99994 on facial grimacing and allodynia in mice postsurgery: a comparative study with known analgesics.
Pain Assessment and Measurement.author: McCoy ES, Ryan DF, Park SK, Zylka MJ
Pain Assessment and Measurement.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the NK1R antagonist CP-99994 using a machine learning-based facial grimacing score in mice after surgery. While standard analgesics like carprofen and buprenorphine effectively reduced grimacing, CP-99994 showed limited efficacy on this spontaneous pain measure, despite reducing evoked mechanical allodynia. The findings suggest that assessing spontaneous pain behaviors like facial grimacing may better predict the clinical analgesic potential of drug candidates.

Pain Assessment and Measurement.title: Peripheral contributions to offset analgesia: effects of stimulus duration, intensity, and location.
Pain Assessment and Measurement.author: Sun P, Wong APH, Asplund CL, Derbyshire SWG
Pain Assessment and Measurement.abstract_summary: This study investigated the peripheral nerve fiber contributions to offset analgesia (OA), a phenomenon of profound pain reduction after a small decrease in a noxious stimulus. By applying heat stimuli of varying durations and intensities to the hand, the results suggest that the slower-responding CMH nociceptors are critical for generating OA. The findings also indicate that the faster-responding AMH-I and AMH-II nociceptors are neither necessary nor sufficient for the effect.

Pain Assessment and Measurement.title: Reliability and validity of the Pediatric PainSCAN: a screening tool for pediatric neuropathic pain and complex regional pain syndrome.
Pain Assessment and Measurement.author: Mesaroli G, Davis AM, Perruccio AV, Davidge KM, Campbell F, Sun N; Walker SM, Hess CW, Simons LE, Logan D, Stinson JN
Pain Assessment and Measurement.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the reliability and validity of the Pediatric PainSCAN, a new screening tool for neuropathic pain (NP) and complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) in children. Tested in 221 pediatric patients, the tool demonstrated sufficient test-retest reliability and criterion validity for identifying CRPS and NP. The study confirms that the Pediatric PainSCAN is a reliable and valid tool for use in pediatric chronic pain clinics.

Pain Assessment and Measurement.title: Convergent validity of a person-dependent definition of a low back pain flare.
Pain Assessment and Measurement.author: Suri P, Korpak AM, Timmons AK, Tanus AD, Brubeck HF, Costa N; Staab CA, Hodges PW, Daniels CJ, Heagerty PJ, Jensen MP
Pain Assessment and Measurement.abstract_summary: This prospective study validated a person-dependent definition of a low back pain (LBP) "flare" in a cohort of 465 Veterans. The study found that when participants self-reported being in a flare state, it was significantly associated with a 2.8-point higher pain intensity score on a 0-10 scale. Flare status was also associated with greater pain interference and analgesic use, supporting the convergent validity of this simple, patient-centered definition.

Pain Assessment and Measurement.title: Application of deep learning-based facial pain recognition model for postoperative pain assessment.
Pain Assessment and Measurement.author: Zhang JT, Hu XY, Duan W, Ji MH, Yang JJ
Pain Assessment and Measurement.abstract_summary: This study developed and validated a deep learning model for postoperative pain assessment based on facial expression recognition. Using a dataset of over 3,400 clinical images, the model showed high performance in identifying severe pain, with an AUROC of 0.898. The research demonstrates the potential of using AI-driven facial analysis as a real-time, objective tool for monitoring pain, especially in patients with communication difficulties.

Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.title: Borders that hurt: the link between anti-immigration attitudes in Europe and the epidemic of chronic pain in immigrant adolescents.
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.author: Roman-Juan J, Hood AM, Marbil MG, Birnie KA, Noel M
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.abstract_summary: This study examined the link between country-level anti-immigration attitudes and chronic pain prevalence in over 5,600 immigrant adolescents across 20 European countries. The results showed a significant association: stronger anti-immigration attitudes in a country were linked to a higher prevalence of chronic pain among its immigrant adolescents. This effect was even stronger for immigrants with low socioeconomic status, highlighting how sociopolitical exclusion can be a public health burden.

Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.title: Familial risk of carpal tunnel syndrome among first-degree relatives and interaction with obesity and hyperglycemia-a population-based study in Korea.
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.author: Kim JE, Kim B, Kim HJ, Hwang J, Swan H, Kim YS; Cha J, Kang T, Kim KH, Kim M, Hann HJ, Kim KU, Ahn HS
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.abstract_summary: This large, population-based study in Korea investigated the familial risk of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). Individuals with an affected first-degree relative had a nearly two-fold increased risk of developing CTS. The study also found a significant gene-environment interaction, where the combined risk from a positive family history and obesity or hyperglycemia was greater than the sum of their individual risks, identifying a high-risk population.

Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.title: High-Flow Nasal Oxygen versus Mechanical Ventilation Through a Laryngeal Mask During General Anesthesia Without Muscle Paralysis: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.author: Frassanito L, Grieco DL, Vassalli F, Piersanti A, Scorzoni M, Ciano F, Zanfini BA, Catarci S, Catena U, Scambia G, Antonelli M, Draisci G
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared high-flow nasal oxygen with laryngeal mask ventilation for respiratory support during 30-minute general anesthesia sessions without muscle paralysis. The study found high-flow oxygen to be non-inferior, with a 99% success rate in both groups. While high-flow oxygen was associated with fewer postoperative respiratory symptoms, it also led to a higher incidence of hypercarbia, warranting careful patient selection and monitoring.

Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.title: Androgen receptors expressed in the primary sensory neurons regulate mechanical pain sensitivity.
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.author: Saika F, Uta D, Fukazawa Y, Hino Y, Hatano Y; Kishioka S, Nawa H, Hino S, Suzuki K, Kiguchi N
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of androgen receptors (AR) in mechanical pain sensitivity using mouse models. Higher testosterone levels in male mice correlated with higher pain thresholds, an effect that was absent in mice lacking AR in their sensory neurons. The study found that primary sensory neurons, especially CGRP+ neurons, are critical targets for androgens in regulating mechanical pain, suggesting a potential therapeutic pathway for pain management.

Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.title: A catheter-associated urinary tract infection mouse model to study bladder dysfunction and pain.
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.author: Schillebeeckx L, Caldwell A, Luyten K, Sliwinska M, Gevaert T; Everaerts W, Voets T
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.abstract_summary: This paper describes the development of a female mouse model for catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) to study bladder pain and dysfunction. The model successfully recapitulates key clinical features, including sustained bacterial infection, biofilm formation, bladder hypersensitivity, and voiding dysfunction. This novel in vivo model provides a valuable tool for investigating the mechanisms of CAUTI and testing new therapies.

Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.title: Identifying risk and protective factors in the transmission of chronic pain from mothers to children: a longitudinal cohort study.
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.author: Beveridge JK, Noel M, McArthur BA, Madigan S, Orr SL, McDonald S; Tough S, Birnie KA
Genetics and Sociodemographics of Pain.abstract_summary: This longitudinal study of 1,128 mother-child dyads investigated the transmission of chronic pain. Children of mothers with chronic pain had increased odds of developing chronic pain themselves, particularly if the mother also had high anxiety or used ineffective parenting practices. Child-specific factors like optimism and strong connections with adults were found to be protective, lowering the odds of chronic pain for all children, regardless of maternal pain status.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: Cortical astrocyte activation triggers meningeal nociception and migraine-like pain.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Bree D, Zhao J, Stratton J, Levy D
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study investigated whether activating cortical astrocytes is sufficient to trigger migraine pain. Using a chemogenetic approach in a rat model, researchers found that activating astrocytes in the visual cortex was sufficient to induce prolonged firing and sensitization of meningeal nociceptors, as well as migraine-like pain behaviors. These effects were suppressed by a CGRP-blocking antibody, suggesting that cortical astrocyte activation can be a direct trigger for migraine pain.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: Prior use-dependent plasticity triggers different individual corticomotor responses during persistent musculoskeletal pain.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Zamorano AM, Kleber B, De Martino E, Insausti-Delgado A, Vuust P; Flor H, Graven-Nielsen T
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study explored how prior motor experience (use-dependent plasticity) influences corticomotor responses to persistent musculoskeletal pain, comparing musicians to non-musicians. After inducing prolonged pain with an NGF injection, non-musicians showed a reduction in motor map volume and higher pain intensity, while musicians, who had smaller motor maps at baseline, did not. The findings demonstrate that pre-existing plasticity from motor training can counteract the effects of prolonged pain on the motor system.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: A ligand-receptor interactome of the bone tumor microenvironment in multiple myeloma bone pain.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Barakat A, Doncheva NT, Prado J, Moll L, Jensen JL; Diaz-delCastillo M, Novak I, Eijkelkamp N, Jensen LJ, Heegaard AM
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study used computational analysis of transcriptomic data to map the ligand-receptor interactions that contribute to multiple myeloma bone pain. By identifying cell-type-specific interactions between the tumor microenvironment and sensory neurons, the research pinpointed potential nociceptive signaling pathways. The study suggests potential targets for future analgesic drug development, including specific ligands and their upstream regulatory kinases.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: Microglia-neuronal communication mediated by P2X4R-BDNF-TrkB promotes synaptic plasticity and anterior cingulate cortex hyperactivity in muscle pain chronicity.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Liang Y, Luo M, Xu Q, Zhang S, Niu S, Li X; Sun W, Song M, Wang L, Xing X, Wang J, Feng M, Zhao L; Chen H, Sheng R, Wang Y
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of microglia-neuronal communication in the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) in chronic muscle pain. The findings reveal that microglial P2X4R promotes the release of BDNF, which then acts on neuronal TrkB receptors to enhance synaptic plasticity and neuronal excitability. This signaling cascade contributes to ACC hyperactivity and the maintenance of chronic muscle pain, identifying a potential therapeutic target.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: A combined activity of peripheral nociceptive and nonnociceptive neurons is necessary to trigger spinal microglial reactivity and sustained pain.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Isler M, Chu Sin Chung P, Deftu AF, Kirschmann G, Decosterd I, Suter MR
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study investigated the triggers for spinal microglial reactivity, a key step in developing chronic pain. Using optogenetic and electrical stimulation in mice, researchers found that activating either nociceptive or non-nociceptive peripheral fibers alone was not enough to cause sustained pain or a microglial response. Only the simultaneous activation of both fiber types induced sustained hypersensitivity and spinal microglial changes, suggesting that a combination of sensory inputs is necessary to initiate these chronic pain mechanisms.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: Coding of post-surgical pain in ICD-11: between conceptual richness and practical constraints.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Martinez V, Spagna A, Attal N
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This article discusses the new classification of chronic postsurgical pain in the ICD-11. The authors praise this as a significant step forward in recognizing the condition as a distinct clinical entity. However, they also point out remaining gaps between the conceptual framework, the coding tools, and clinical practice, calling for better integration of diagnostic criteria and improved visibility of neuropathic and psychosocial pain dimensions.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: Orexinergic projections to substantia innominata mediate arousal and analgesia.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Xiang X, Wang F, Chen C, Guan Z, Zhou W
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study investigated the neural circuits underlying arousal and analgesia, focusing on orexinergic neurons projecting from the lateral hypothalamus (LHA) to the substantia innominata (SI). Using optogenetics and other techniques in mice, the researchers found that activating this LHA(OX)-->SI circuit promoted arousal from anesthesia and induced analgesia for both thermal and inflammatory pain. The effects were predominantly mediated through the orexin receptor-2 (OX2R), revealing a key pathway that co-regulates arousal and pain.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: Reliability and validity of the Pediatric PainSCAN: a screening tool for pediatric neuropathic pain and complex regional pain syndrome.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Mesaroli G, Davis AM, Perruccio AV, Davidge KM, Campbell F, Sun N; Walker SM, Hess CW, Simons LE, Logan D, Stinson JN
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the reliability and validity of the Pediatric PainSCAN, a new screening tool for neuropathic pain (NP) and complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) in children. Tested in 221 pediatric patients, the tool demonstrated sufficient test-retest reliability and criterion validity for identifying CRPS and NP. The study confirms that the Pediatric PainSCAN is a reliable and valid tool for use in pediatric chronic pain clinics.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: The impact of chronic pain on brain gene expression.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Collier L, Seah C, Hicks EM, Holtzheimer PE, Krystal JH; Girgenti MJ, Huckins LM, Johnston KJA
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study investigated brain gene expression associated with chronic pain using postmortem brain tissue from 304 donors. The analysis identified over 2,000 cell-type-specific differentially expressed genes (DEGs), which were significantly enriched in the microglia of the basolateral amygdala (BLA). These findings highlight BLA microglia as a key cell type in chronic pain and reveal enrichment for immune and hypoxia-related pathways, providing new insights into the molecular underpinnings of the condition.

Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.title: Spinal disk injury induces germinal center formation, pronociceptive antibody production, and chronic nociceptive sensitization in a male mouse back pain model.
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.author: Wei T, Guo TZ, Shi X, Li WW, Clark JD, Kingery WS
Neurobiology of Pain and Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study used a mouse model of lumbar disk puncture to investigate the role of the adaptive immune system in chronic back pain. The results showed that disk injury led to the formation of B-cell germinal centers in lymph nodes and the production of pronociceptive IgM and IgG antibodies, which peaked weeks after the initial injury. These findings support the hypothesis that autoimmunity contributes to the transition from acute tissue injury to a chronic musculoskeletal pain state.

Intrathecal Drug Delivery for Cancer Pai.title: Intrathecal Drug Delivery System in Prepontine Cistern for Patients with Intractable Craniofacial Cancer Pain: A Multicenter Retrospective Study.
Intrathecal Drug Delivery for Cancer Pai.author: Long D, Li X, Zhang Y, Luo J, Liu B, Hong B, Yang F, Zou C; Ge F, Zhang A, Zhou H, Xiao Y, Wang Y
Intrathecal Drug Delivery for Cancer Pai.abstract_summary: This multicenter retrospective study evaluated the safety and efficacy of placing an intrathecal morphine pump catheter in the prepontine cistern for treating intractable craniofacial cancer pain. In 33 patients, this approach resulted in a significant and progressive reduction in pain scores and breakthrough pain episodes over 30 days. The technique effectively relieved pain with an extremely low morphine dose requirement and few adverse events.

Fibromyalgia and Sleep Interventions.title: Analgesic benefits of pharmacological and nonpharmacological sleep interventions for adults with fibromyalgia: a systematic review and meta-analyses.
Fibromyalgia and Sleep Interventions.author: Abolhosseini S, Malatesta A, Asmundson AJN, Gilron I, Salomons TV
Fibromyalgia and Sleep Interventions.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis evaluated whether sleep-focused interventions can reduce pain in adults with fibromyalgia. The analysis of 19 studies found that sodium oxybate and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia both significantly improved pain outcomes compared to placebo or usual care, respectively. The findings provide preliminary support for the analgesic benefits of certain sleep interventions for fibromyalgia patients.

Headache Management.title: Practice advisory for intravenous management of headache disorders in hospitalized patients: a review of the evidence and consensus recommendations.
Headache Management.author: Hoydonckx Y, Feoktistov A, Amoozegar F, Anderson CC, Barad M, Burke E; Chitsantikul P, Doshi TL, Englesakis M, Goel A, Gupta H, Kissoon N; Kirschner A, Kohan L, Lauritsen CG, Miller F, Monsour D, Nader A; Ogunlaja O, Schuster N, Schwenk ES, Silberstein SD, Souza D, Yuan H; Narouze S
Headache Management.abstract_summary: This practice advisory from the American Society of Regional Anesthesia and Pain Medicine provides evidence-based recommendations for the intravenous management of headache disorders in hospitalized patients. Through a systematic literature review and a modified Delphi process, the panel generated 12 statements and 17 recommendations. The advisory aims to standardize inpatient headache care and highlights the need for more rigorous research in this area.

Chronic Itch Mechanisms.title: Upregulated natriuretic peptide B expression as a hallmark of chronic itch.
Chronic Itch Mechanisms.author: Tseng PY, Liew HL, Ringkamp M, Nagao K, Hoon MA
Chronic Itch Mechanisms.abstract_summary: This study sought to identify common molecular features of chronic itch by analyzing transcriptomic data from multiple mouse and monkey models of itch and pain. The analysis revealed that the upregulation of natriuretic peptide B (Nppb) expression in sensory neurons is a consistent and selective feature of chronic itch, but not chronic pain. The findings suggest that increased Nppb expression may contribute to chronic itch and could serve as a conserved biomarker for the condition.

Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.title: Frailty and perioperative outcomes: SNAP-3 as a call to action.
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.author: McIsaac DI, Amado L
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.abstract_summary: This commentary on the SNAP-3 study emphasizes that frailty is a major risk factor for poor outcomes in older surgical patients. The authors call for routine identification of at-risk patients (Clinical Frailty Scale >=4) and a shift in research focus from risk identification to developing interventions that improve outcomes for this growing population.
