Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.title: Frailty in the perioperative setting: lessons from SNAP-3.
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.author: Howell SJ, Dhesi JK
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.abstract_summary: This article reviews the findings of the SNAP-3 study, the largest UK study on frailty in older surgical patients. It highlights that frailty, found in one-fifth of patients, is a strong predictor of adverse outcomes like longer hospital stays, delirium, and mortality, whereas multimorbidity alone is not. The study advocates for routine frailty screening and the development of specialized perioperative services.

Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.title: Postoperative outcomes in older patients living with frailty and multimorbidity in the UK: SNAP-3, a snapshot observational study.
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.author: Swarbrick CJ, Williams K, Evans B, Blake HA, Poulton T; Nava S, Shah A, Martin P, Partridge JSL, Moppett IK
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.abstract_summary: This large prospective observational study (SNAP-3) involving over 7,000 older UK surgical patients confirms the significant impact of frailty on postoperative outcomes. Increasing frailty was strongly associated with longer hospital stays, and higher rates of delirium, morbidity, and mortality. In contrast, multimorbidity alone had a less pronounced impact, mainly affecting postoperative morbidity, highlighting the critical need to address frailty in surgical planning.

Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.title: Directed acyclic graphs to minimise bias and optimise causal inference in SNAP-3: an observational cohort study of frailty, multimorbidity, and delirium in older surgical patients.
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.author: Swarbrick CJ, Blake HA, Martin P, Partridge JSL, Moppett IK
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.abstract_summary: This article describes the development and application of directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) to guide the statistical analysis of the SNAP-3 observational cohort study. By visually mapping the causal assumptions between variables like frailty, multimorbidity, and postoperative outcomes, DAGs provide a transparent and objective framework for minimizing bias. This approach helps to strengthen causal inference in observational research.

Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.title: Frailty and intraoperative hypotension: is the risk significant and modifiable?
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.author: Schnetz M, Zakaria L, Ahuja S, Khanna AK
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent paper demonstrating that frail patients are more likely to experience intraoperative hypotension, and that these two factors work together to increase postoperative risk. The authors highlight that both frailty and hypotension are modifiable risk factors that can be addressed through interventions like prehabilitation and continuous hemodynamic monitoring. They call for future studies to define which interventions are most beneficial for frail surgical patients.

Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.title: DAGs for dummies: how to extract causation from correlation.
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.author: Gaskell A, Sleigh J
Frailty and Perioperative Outcomes.abstract_summary: This article provides an introduction to the foundational principles of directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) as a tool for causal inference in observational research. Using the recent DAG-guided work from the SNAP-3 project as an example, the authors explain how DAGs offer a structured approach to depict causal relationships and distinguish likely causation from mere association. This framework helps in selecting appropriate variables for adjustment and avoiding common biases.

Benzodiazepine Use and Postoperative Del.title: Long-term and pre-operative benzodiazepine use in older adults and risk for postoperative delirium: An additional analysis of the multicentre Biomarker Development for Postoperative Cognitive Impairment in the Elderly Study.
Benzodiazepine Use and Postoperative Del.author: Starks SCE, Pohrt A, Halzl-Yurek F, Heinrich M, Muller A; Spies CD, Winterer G, Zacharias N
Benzodiazepine Use and Postoperative Del.abstract_summary: This analysis of the BioCog cohort study investigated the link between benzodiazepine use and postoperative delirium (POD) in older surgical patients. The study found that long-term benzodiazepine use was significantly associated with an increased risk of developing POD, regardless of sex. In contrast, using benzodiazepines as a single premedication dose just before surgery was not associated with a higher POD risk.

Trends in Total Joint Arthroplasty for t.title: Trends in Comorbidities and Complications Among Octogenarians and Nonagenarians Undergoing Primary Total Joint Arthroplasty in the United States.
Trends in Total Joint Arthroplasty for t.author: Reisinger L, Cozowicz C, Zhong H, Illescas A, Giannakis P; Memtsoudis SG, Poeran J, Liu J
Trends in Total Joint Arthroplasty for t.abstract_summary: This large database study analyzed trends for patients aged 80 and older undergoing total knee and hip arthroplasty (TKA, THA) from 2006 to 2022. While these older patients undergoing TKA surprisingly had fewer comorbidities than a 65-70 year-old reference group, they still had significantly higher odds of major complications. The study underscores that advanced age itself remains a significant independent risk factor for increased perioperative morbidity.

Dexmedetomidine for Postoperative Deliri.title: Preoperative low-dose dexmedetomidine reduces postoperative delirium in elderly patients with hip fracture under spinal anesthesia: A randomized, double blind, controlled clinical study.
Dexmedetomidine for Postoperative Deliri.author: Geng P, Shang Z, Cheng F, Zhang Y, Deng X; Chen X, Zhan L, Zheng L, Liu X
Dexmedetomidine for Postoperative Deliri.abstract_summary: This randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial evaluated the effect of a continuous overnight infusion of low-dose dexmedetomidine on postoperative delirium (POD) in elderly patients undergoing hip fracture surgery. The study found that dexmedetomidine significantly reduced the incidence of POD (10.3% vs. 22.2% in the placebo group). This was associated with improved preoperative sleep quality and lower postoperative C-reactive protein levels.

Palliative Pain Management in Hip Fractu.title: Chemical hip denervation using phenol via Pericapsular Nerve Group (PENG) block in palliative non-operative management for frail older hip fracture patients: A multicenter retrospective cohort study.
Palliative Pain Management in Hip Fractu.author: Kroes T, Wijnen HH, Bos K, Wasmoeth LG, van de Vossenberg G, Spaetgens B; Smits RJH, Schuijt HJ, Willems HC
Palliative Pain Management in Hip Fractu.abstract_summary: This multicenter retrospective study evaluated the use of chemical hip denervation with phenol via a PENG block for palliative pain management in 185 frail older patients with hip fractures. The procedure resulted in acceptable pain control for the majority of patients, with low opioid requirements. The findings suggest that this technique is a viable analgesic option as part of person-centered, multidisciplinary palliative care in this vulnerable population.

Post-discharge Digital Health Interventi.title: Post discharge digital health technology interventions in ambulatory surgery: A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Post-discharge Digital Health Interventi.author: Bentsen SB, Stjernberg M, Raeder J, Eide GE, Tvedt MN, Hegland PA
Post-discharge Digital Health Interventi.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of six randomized controlled trials evaluated the effects of post-discharge digital health interventions (DHIs) for ambulatory surgery patients. The meta-analysis found no significant effect of DHIs on postoperative pain or unplanned healthcare encounters. However, individual studies suggested DHIs may reduce some symptoms, lower costs, and improve quality of life, though the overall certainty of evidence was low.

Smartphone App for Postoperative Recover.title: Postsurgical Medication Awareness, Recovery, and Tracking using a Phone-Based App (SMART-APP): a randomized clinical trial.
Smartphone App for Postoperative Recover.author: Rolfzen ML, Shah K, Sanchez Rodriguez E, Hoffman JT, Clauw D; Mascha E, Graff V, Bartels K
Smartphone App for Postoperative Recover.abstract_summary: This randomized trial tested whether a patient-facing educational smartphone app could reduce postoperative opioid use compared to a data-collection-only app. The study, involving 606 surgical inpatients, found no significant difference in self-reported opioid consumption in the four weeks after discharge between the educational app and control groups. The results suggest that for this population with low post-discharge opioid needs, the app did not alter consumption.

Rebound Pain after Regional Anesthesia.title: Factors associated with a reduction in the preventive effect of intravenous dexamethasone on rebound pain after axillary brachial plexus block.
Rebound Pain after Regional Anesthesia.author: Touil N, Pavlopoulou A, Barbier O, Libouton X, Gruson D; Gala JL, Lavand'homme P
Rebound Pain after Regional Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This prospective study investigated factors that reduce the effectiveness of intravenous dexamethasone for preventing rebound pain after axillary brachial plexus block. The study found that preoperative nocturnal pain, severe anxiety, high pain catastrophizing, and low salivary cortisol levels were all associated with an increased risk of rebound pain despite dexamethasone use. These findings support the development of personalized preventive strategies.

Ketamine Use in Mechanically Ventilated.title: Ketamine Analgo-sedation for Mechanically Ventilated Critically Ill Adults: A Rapid Practice Guideline from the Saudi Critical Care Society and the Scandinavian Society of Anesthesiology and Intensive Care Medicine.
Ketamine Use in Mechanically Ventilated.author: Amer M, Hylander Moller M, Alshahrani M, Shehabi Y, Arabi YM, Alshamsi F; Ingi Sigurethsson M, Rehn M, Chew MS, Kalliomaki ML, Lewis K; Al-Suwaidan FA, Al-Dorzi HM, Al-Fares A, Alsadoon N, Bell CM; Groth CM, Parke R, Mehta S, Wischmeyer PE, Al-Omari A, Olkkola KT; Alhazzani W
Ketamine Use in Mechanically Ventilated.abstract_summary: This rapid practice guideline provides recommendations on ketamine for analgo-sedation in critically ill, mechanically ventilated adults. Based on a systematic review, the panel conditionally recommends against using ketamine as a monotherapy when other agents are available due to uncertain effects. They also provide a conditional recommendation for using ketamine as an adjunct to other sedatives or continuing with non-ketamine sedatives alone, highlighting the need for more research.

Nutrition and Ventilator Weaning.title: Potential Benefits of Medical Nutrition Therapy for Timely Ventilator Weaning in the Critically Ill.
Nutrition and Ventilator Weaning.author: De Rosa S, Rauseo M, Umbrello M, Lassola S, Battaglini D
Nutrition and Ventilator Weaning.abstract_summary: This review explores the critical role of nutritional support and metabolic assessment in weaning patients from mechanical ventilation. It discusses strategies like indirect calorimetry and diaphragm ultrasound for monitoring, and highlights the controversy around protein intake, suggesting a moderate, individualized approach may be best. The authors conclude that a personalized nutritional strategy, including vitamin D optimization, can improve weaning success and post-ICU outcomes.

Rapid Response System and ICU Admission.title: Impact of the Standardized ICU Admission Ratio on Outcomes in Rapid Response System Activations: A Retrospective Multicenter Study in Japan.
Rapid Response System and ICU Admission.author: Ono S, Uchino S, Tokito M, Saito T, Sasabuchi Y, Sanui M
Rapid Response System and ICU Admission.abstract_summary: This multicenter retrospective study in Japan examined the association between institutional ICU admission rates after Rapid Response System (RRS) activation and patient outcomes. Using a Standardized ICU Admission Ratio (SIAR), the study found that higher SIAR values were significantly associated with a lower incidence of poor neurological outcome or death within 30 days. The findings suggest that greater ICU utilization following RRS calls may improve patient outcomes.

Outcomes of Alcohol-related Liver Diseas.title: Outcomes for patients with alcohol-related liver disease admitted to Scottish intensive care units 2010-2018.
Outcomes of Alcohol-related Liver Diseas.author: Shariff A, Rhode S, Forbes SJ, Lone N, Docherty A
Outcomes of Alcohol-related Liver Diseas.abstract_summary: This study analyzed outcomes for patients with alcohol-related liver disease (ARLD) admitted to Scottish ICUs and found they had significantly higher ICU mortality (36.7%) compared to patients without ARLD (22.5%). Mortality increased with the level of organ support required, but nearly one-fifth of those on multi-organ support survived to discharge. The study suggests a trial of organ support may be appropriate, especially for patients admitted with a gastrointestinal bleed, who had lower mortality.

Postoperative Hypotension on General War.title: New-onset postoperative hypotension in patients recovering from noncardiac surgery: A prospective observational study.
Postoperative Hypotension on General War.author: Hoppe P, Chang Y, Schwarz T, Bergholz A, Thomsen KK; Kroker A, Flick M, Krause L, Sessler DI, Saugel B
Postoperative Hypotension on General War.abstract_summary: This prospective observational study monitored arterial pressure in 248 patients on general wards after noncardiac surgery. It found that while 41% of patients had at least one mean arterial pressure reading below 65 mmHg, this constituted new-onset hypotension (at least 5 mmHg below their preoperative low) in only 18% of the total cohort. The study highlights the importance of distinguishing new-onset hypotension from a patient's normal baseline pressure range.

Kidney Transplantation.title: Reversal of rocuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade by sugammadex in patients undergoing kidney transplantation: Pharmacokinetics, efficacy, and safety analyses.
Kidney Transplantation.author: Tang Y, Feng Y, Jia B, Long W, Chen Q, Gu S, Zhao G; Xu B
Kidney Transplantation.abstract_summary: This study investigated the pharmacokinetics of sugammadex in patients with end-stage renal disease undergoing kidney transplantation compared to healthy controls. The elimination half-life of sugammadex was significantly longer in renal failure patients (10 hours vs. 2 hours), and plasma clearance was much lower. Despite these pharmacokinetic differences, a 2 mg/kg dose of sugammadex provided safe and effective reversal of neuromuscular blockade in the transplant patients.
